speech.line: Good Lords, make all the ſpeedie haſt you may.
Say, Vnckle Gloceſter, if our Brother come,
Where ſhall we ſoiourne, till our Coronation?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Where it think’ſt beſt vnto your Royall ſelfe.
If I may counſaile you, ſome day or two
Your Highneſſe ſhall repoſe you at the Tower:
Then where you pleaſe, and ſhall be thought moſt ﬁt
For your beſt health, and recreation.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I dœ not like the Tower, of any place:
Did Iulius Cæſar build that place, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: He did, my gracious Lord, begin that place,
Which ſince, ſucceeding Ages haue re-edify’d.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Is it vpon record? or elſe reported
Succeſſiuely from age to age, he built it?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Vpon record, my gracious Lord.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: But ſay, my Lord, it were not regiſtred,
Me thinkes the truth ſhould liue from age to age,
As ’twere retayl’d to all poſteritie,
Euen to the generall ending day.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: So wiſe, ſo young, they ſay dœ neuer liue long.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: What ſay you, Vnckle?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I ſay, without Charaers, Fame liues long.
Thus, like the formall Vice, Iniquitie,
I morallize two meanings in one word.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: That Iulius Cæſar was a famous man,
With what his Valour did enrich his Wit,
His Wit ſet downe, to make his Valour liue:
Death makes no Conqueſt of his Conqueror,
For now he liues in Fame, though not in Life.
Ile tell you what, my Couſin Buckingham.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: What, my gracious Lord?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: And if I liue vntill I be a man,
Ile win our ancient Right in France againe,
Or dye a Souldier, as I liu’d a King.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Short Summers lightly haue a forward Spring.

scene.stagedir: Enter young Yorke, Haſtings, and Cardinall.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Now in good time, heere comes the Duke of
Yorke.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Richard of Yorke, how fares our Noble Bro —
ther?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Well, my deare Lord, ſo muſt I call you now.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I, Brother, to our griefe, as it is yours:
Too late he dy’d, that might haue kept that Title,
Which by his death hath loſt much Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: How fares our Couſin, Noble Lord of Yorke?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I thanke you, gentle Vnckle. O my Lord,
You ſaid, that idle Weeds are faſt in growth:
The Prince, my Brother, hath out-growne me farre.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: He hath, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: And therefore is he idle?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Oh my faire Couſin, I muſt not ſay ſo.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Then he is more beholding to you, then I.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: He may command me as my Soueraigne,
But you haue power in me, as in a Kinſman.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I pray you, Vnckle, giue me this Dagger.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: My Dagger, little Couſin? with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: A Begger, Brother?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Of my kind Vnckle, that I know will giue,
And being but a Toy, which is no griefe to giue.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: A greater giﬅ then that, Ile giue my Couſin.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: A greater giﬅ? O, that’s the Sword to it.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I, gentle Couſin, were it light enough.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: O then I ſee, you will part but with light giﬅs,
In weightier things you’le ſay a Begger nay.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: It is too weightie for your Grace to weare.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I weigh it lightly, were it heauier.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: What, would you haue my Weapon, little Lord?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I would that I might thanke you, as, as, you
call me.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Little.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: My Lord of Yorke will ſtill be croſſe in talke:
Vnckle, your Grace knowes how to beare with him.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: You meane to beare me, not to beare with me:
Vnckle, my Brother mockes both you and me,
Becauſe that I am little, like an Ape,
He thinkes that you ſhould beare me on your ſhoulders.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: With what a ſharpe prouided wit he reaſons:
To mittigate the ſcorne he giues his Vnckle,
He prettily and aptly taunts himſelfe:
So cunning, and ſo young, is wonderfull.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: My Lord, wilt pleaſe you paſſe along?
My ſelfe, and my good Couſin Buckingham,
Will to your Mother, to entreat of her
To meet you at the Tower, and welcome you.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: What, will you gœ vnto the Tower, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: My Lord Proteor will haue it ſo.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I ſhall not ſleepe in quiet at the Tower.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Why, what ſhould you feare?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Marry, my Vnckle Clarence angry Ghoſt:
My Grandam told me he was murther’d there.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I feare no Vnckles dead.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Nor none that liue, I hope.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: And if they liue, I hope I need not feare.
But come my Lord: and with a heauie heart,
Thinking on them, gœ I vnto the Tower.

scene.stagedir: A Senet. Exeunt Prince, Yorke, Haſtings, and Dorſet.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Thinke you, my Lord, this little prating Yorke
Was not incenſed by his ſubtile Mother,
To taunt and ſcorne you thus opprobriouſly?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: No doubt, no doubt: Oh ’tis a perillous Boy,
Bold, quicke, ingenious, forward, capable:
Hee is all the Mothers, from the top to tœ.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Well, let them reſt: Come hither Catesby,
Thou art ſworne as deepely to effe what we intend,
As cloſely to conceale what we impart:
Thou know’ſt our reaſons vrg’d vpon the way.
What think’ſt thou? is it not an eaſie matter,
To make William Lord Haſtings of our minde,
For the inſtallment of this Noble Duke
In the Seat Royall of this famous Ile?

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: He for his fathers ſake ſo loues the Prince,
That he will not be wonne to ought againſt him.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: What think’ſt thou then of Stanley? Will
not hee?

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: Hee will dœ all in all as Haſtings doth.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Well then, no more but this:
Gœ gentle Catesby, and as it were farre off,
Sound thou Lord Haſtings,
How he doth ſtand affeed to our purpoſe,
And ſummon him to morrow to the Tower,
To ſit about the Coronation.
If thou do’ſt ﬁnde him traable to vs,
Encourage him, and tell him all our reaſons:
If he be leaden, ycie, cold, vnwilling,
Be thou ſo too, and ſo breake off the talke,
And giue vs notice of his inclination:
For we to morrow hold diuided Councels,
Wherein thy ſelfe ſhalt highly be employ’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Commend me to Lord William: tell him Catesby,
His ancient Knot of dangerous Aduerſaries
To morrow are let blood at Pomfret Caſtle,
And bid my Lord, for ioy of this good newes,
Giue Miſtreſſe Shore one gentle Kiſſe the more.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Good Catesby, gœ effe this buſineſſe ſoundly.

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: My good Lords both, with all the heed I can.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Shall we heare from you, Catesby, ere we ſleepe?

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: You ſhall, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: At Crosby Houſ, there ſhall you ﬁnd vs both.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Now, my Lord,
What ſhall wee dœ, if wee perceiue
Lord Haſtings will not yeeld to our Complots?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Chop off his Head:
Something wee will determine:
And looke when I am King, clayme thou of me
The Earledome of Hereford, and all the moueables
Whereof the King, my Brother, was poſſeſt.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Ile clayme that promiſe at your Graces hand.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And looke to haue it yeelded with all kindneſſe.
Come, let vs ſuppe betimes, that aﬅerwards
Wee may digeſt our complots in ſome forme.

scene.stagedir: Enter a Meſſenger to the Doore of Haſtings.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: My Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Who knockes?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: One from the Lord Stanley.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: What is’t a Clocke?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Vpon the ſtroke of foure.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Cannot my Lord Stanley ſleepe theſe tedious
Nights?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: So it appeares, by that I haue to ſay:
Firſt, he commends him to your Noble ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Then certiﬁes your Lordſhip, that this Night
He dreamt, the Bore had raſed off his Helme:
Beſides, he ſayes there are two Councels kept;
And that may be determin’d at the one,
Which may make you and him to rue at th’ other.
Therefore he ſends to know your Lordſhips pleaſure,
If you will preſently take Horſe with him,
And with all ſpeed poſt with him toward the North,
To ſhun the danger that his Soule diuines.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Gœ fellow, gœ, returne vnto thy Lord,
Bid him not feare the ſeperated Councell:
His Honor and my ſelfe are at the one,
And at the other, is my good friend Catesby;
Where nothing can proceede, that toucheth vs,
Whereof I ſhall not haue intelligence:
Tell him his Feares are ſhallow, without inſtance.
And for his Dreames, I wonder hee’s ſo ſimple,
To truſt the mock’ry of vnquiet ſlumbers.
To ﬂye the Bore, before the Bore purſues,
Were to incenſe the Bore to follow vs,
And make purſuit, where he did meane no chaſe.
Goe, bid thy Maſter riſe, and come to me,
And we will both together to the Tower,
Where he ſhall ſee the Bore will vſe vs kindly.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Ile gœ, my Lord, and tell him what you ſay.

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: Many good morrowes to my Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Good morrow Catesby, you are early ſtirring:
What newes, what newes, in this our tott’ring State?

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: It is a reeling World indeed, my Lord:
And I beleeue will neuer ſtand vpright,
Till Richard weare the Garland of the Realme.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: How weare the Garland?
Dœſt thou meane the Crowne?

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: I, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Ile haue this Crown of mine cut frō my ſhoulders,
Before Ile ſee the Crowne ſo foule miſ-plac’d:
But canſt thou gueſſe, that he doth ayme at it?

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: I, on my life, and hopes to ﬁnd you forward,
Vpon his partie, for the gaine thereof:
And thereupon he ſends you this good newes,
That this ſame very day your enemies,
The Kindred of the Queene, muſt dye at Pomfret.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Indeed I am no mourner for that newes,
Becauſe they haue beene ſtill my aduerſaries:
But, that Ile giue my voice on Richards ſide,
To barre my Maſters Heires in true Deſcent,
God knowes I will not dœ it, to the death.

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: God keepe your Lordſhip in that gracious
minde.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: But I ſhall laugh at this a twelue-month hence,
That they which brought me in my Maſters hate,
I liue to looke vpon their Tragedie.
Well Catesby, ere a fort-night make me older,
Ile ſend ſome packing, that yet thinke not on’t.

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: ’Tis a vile thing to dye, my gracious Lord,
When men are vnprepar’d, and looke not for it.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: O monſtrous, monſtrous! and ſo falls it out
With Riuers, Vaughan, Grey: and ſo ’twill dœ
With ſome men elſe, that thinke themſelues as ſafe
As thou and I, who (as thou know’ſt) are deare
To Princely Richard, and to Buckingham.

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: The Princes both make high account of you,
For they account his Head vpon the Bridge.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: I know they dœ, and I haue well deſeru’d it.
Come on, come on, where is your Bore-ſpeare man?
Feare you the Bore, and gœ ſo vnprouided?

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: My Lord good morrow, good morrow Catesby:
You may ieaſt on, but by the holy Rood,
I dœ not like theſe ſeuerall Councels, I.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: My Lord, I hold my Life as deare as yours,
And neuer in my dayes, I dœ proteſt,
Was it ſo precious to me, as ’tis now:
Thinke you, but that I know our ſtate ſecure,
I would be ſo triumphant as I am?

speech.speaker: Sta.
speech.line: The Lords at Pomfret, whē they rode from London,
Were iocund, and ſuppos’d their ſtates were ſure,
And they indeed had no cauſe to miſtruſt:
But yet you ſee, how ſoone the Day o’re-caſt.
This ſudden ſtab of Rancour I miſdoubt:
Pray God (I ſay) I proue a needleſſe Coward.
What, ſhall we toward the Tower? the day is ſpent.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Come, come, haue with you:
Wot you what, my Lord,
To day the Lords you talke of, are beheaded.

speech.speaker: Sta.
speech.line: They, for their truth, might better wear their Heads,
Then ſome that haue accus’d them, weare their Hats.
But come, my Lord, let’s away.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Gœ on before, Ile talke with this good fellow.
How now, Sirrha? how gœs the World with thee?

speech.speaker: Purſ.
speech.line: The better, that your Lordſhip pleaſe to aske.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: I tell thee man, ’tis better with me now,
Then when thou met’ſt me laſt, where now we meet:
Then was I going Priſoner to the Tower,
By the ſuggeſtion of the Queenes Allyes.
But now I tell thee (keepe it to thy ſelfe)
This day thoſe Enemies are put to death,
And I in better ſtate then ere I was.

speech.speaker: Purſ.
speech.line: God hold it, to your Honors good content.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Gramercie fellow: there, drinke that for me.

speech.speaker: Purſ.
speech.line: I thanke your Honor.

speech.speaker: Prieſt.
speech.line: Well met, my Lord, I am glad to ſee your Ho —
nor.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: I thanke thee, good Sir Iohn, with all my heart.
I am in your debt, for your laſt Exerciſe:
Come the next Sabboth, and I will content you.

speech.speaker: Prieſt.
speech.line: Ile wait vpon your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: What, talking with a Prieſt, Lord Chamberlaine?
Your friends at Pomfret, they dœ need the Prieſt,
Your Honor hath no ſhriuing worke in hand.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Good faith, and when I met this holy man,
The men you talke of, came into my minde.
What, gœ you toward the Tower?

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: I dœ, my Lord, but long I cannot ſtay there:
I ſhall returne before your Lordſhip, thence.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Nay like enough, for I ſtay Dinner there.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: And Supper too, although thou know’ſt it not.
Come, will you gœ?

speech.speaker: haſt
speech.line: Ile wait vpon your Lordſhip.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sir Richard Ratcliffe, with Halberds, carrying the Nobles to death at Pomfret.

speech.speaker: Riuers.
speech.line: Sir Richard Ratcliffe, let me tell thee this,
To day ſhalt thou behold a Subie die,
For Truth, for Dutie, and for Loyaltie.

speech.speaker: Grey.
speech.line: God bleſſe the Prince from all the Pack of you,
A Knot you are, of damned Blood-ſuckers.

speech.speaker: Vaugh.
speech.line: You liue, that ſhall cry wœ for this heere —
aﬅer.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Diſpatch, the limit of your Liues is out.

speech.speaker: Riuers.
speech.line: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody Priſon!
Fatall and ominous to Noble Peeres:
Within the guiltie Cloſure of thy Walls,
Richard the Second here was hackt to death:
And for more ſlander to thy diſmall Seat,
Wee giue to thee our guiltleſſe blood to drinke.

speech.speaker: Grey.
speech.line: Now Margarets Curſe is falne vpon our Heads,
When ſhee exclaim’d on Haſtings, you, and I,
For ſtanding by, when Richard ſtab’d her Sonne.

speech.speaker: Riuers.
speech.line: Then curs’d ſhee Richard,
Then curs’d ſhee Buckingham,
Then curs’d ſhee Haſtings. Oh remember God,
To heare her prayer for them, as now for vs:
And for my Siſter, and her Princely Sonnes,
Be ſatisfy’d, deare God, with our true blood,
Which, as thou know’ſt, vniuſtly muſt be ſpilt.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Make haſte, the houre of death is expiate.

speech.speaker: Riuers.
speech.line: Come Grey, come Vaughan, let vs here embrace.
Farewell, vntill we meet againe in Heauen.

scene.stagedir: Enter Buckingham, Darby, Haſtings, Biſhop of Ely, Norfolke, Ratcliffe, Louell, with others, at a Table.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Now Noble Peeres, the cauſe why we are met,
Is to determine of the Coronation:
In Gods Name ſpeake, when is the Royall day?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Is all things ready for the Royall time?

speech.speaker: Darb.
speech.line: It is, and wants but nomination.

speech.speaker: Ely.
speech.line: To morrow then I iudge a happie day.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Who knowes the Lord Proteors mind herein?
Who is moſt inward with the Noble Duke?

speech.speaker: Ely.
speech.line: Your Grace, we thinke, ſhould ſooneſt know his
minde.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: We know each others Faces: for our Hearts,
He knowes no more of mine, then I of yours,
Or I of his, my Lord, then you of mine:
Lord Haſtings, you and he are neere in loue.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: I thanke his Grace, I know he loues me well:
But for his purpoſe in the Coronation,
I haue not ſounded him, nor he deliuer’d
His gracious pleaſure any way therein:
But you, my Honorable Lords, may name the time,
And in the Dukes behalfe Ile giue my Voice,
Which I preſume hee’le take in gentle part.

speech.speaker: Ely.
speech.line: In happie time, here comes the Duke himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: My Noble Lords, and Couſins all, good morrow:
I haue beene long a ſleeper: but I truſt,
My abſence doth negle no great deſigne,
Which by my preſence might haue beene concluded.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Had you not come vpon your Q my Lord,
William, Lord Haſtings, had pronounc’d your part;
I meane your Voice, for Crowning of the King.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then my Lord Haſtings, no man might be bolder,
His Lordſhip knowes me well, and loues me well.
My Lord of Ely, when I was laſt in Holborne,
I ſaw good Strawberries in your Garden there,
I dœ beſeech you, ſend for ſome of them.

speech.speaker: Ely.
speech.line: Mary and will, my Lord, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Couſin of Buckingham, a word with you.
Catesby hath ſounded Haſtings in our buſineſſe,
And ﬁndes the teſtie Gentleman ſo hot,
That he will loſe his Head, ere giue conſent
His Maſters Child, as worſhipfully he tearmes it,
Shall loſe the Royaltie of Englands Throne.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Withdraw your ſelfe a while, Ile gœ with you.

speech.speaker: Darb.
speech.line: We haue not yet ſet downe this day of Triumph:
To morrow, in my iudgement, is too ſudden,
For I my ſelfe am not ſo well prouided,
As elſe I would be, were the day prolong’d.

speech.speaker: Ely.
speech.line: Where is my Lord, the Duke of Gloſter?
I haue ſent for theſe Strawberries.

speech.speaker: Ha.
speech.line: His Grace looks chearfully & ſmooth this morning,
There’s ſome conceit or other likes him well,
When that he bids good morrow with ſuch ſpirit.
I thinke there’s neuer a man in Chriſtendome
Can leſſer hide his loue, or hate, then hee,
For by his Face ſtraight ſhall you know his Heart.

speech.speaker: Darb.
speech.line: What of his Heart perceiue you in his Face,
By any liuelyhood he ſhew’d to day?

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Mary, that with no man here he is offended:
For were he, he had ſhewne it in his Lookes.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I pray you all, tell me what they deſerue,
That dœ conſpire my death with diuelliſh Plots
Of damned Witchcraﬅ, and that haue preuail’d
Vpon my Body with their Helliſh Charmes.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: The tender loue I beare your Grace, my Lord,
Makes me moſt forward, in this Princely preſence,
To doome th’ Offendors, whoſœ’re they be:
I ſay, my Lord, they haue deſerued death.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then be your eyes the witneſſe of their euill.
Looke how I am bewitch’d: behold, mine Arme
Is like a blaſted Sapling, wither’d vp:
And this is Edwards Wife, that monſtrous Witch,
Conſorted with that Harlot, Strumpet Shore,
That by their Witchcraﬅ thus haue marked me.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: If they haue done this deed, my Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: If? thou Proteor of this damned Strumpet,
Talk’ſt thou to me of Ifs: thou art a Traytor,
Off with his Head; now by Saint Paul I ſweare,
I will not dine, vntill I ſee the ſame.
Louell> and Ratcliffe, looke that it be done:
The reſt that loue me, riſe, and follow me.

scene.stagedir: Manet Louell and Ratcliffe, with the Lord Haſtings.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Wœ, wœ for England, not a whit for me,
For I, too fond, might haue preuented this:
Stanley did dreame, the Bore did rowſe our Helmes,
And I did ſcorne it, and diſdaine to ﬂye:
Three times to day my Foot-Cloth-Horſe did ſtumble,
And ſtarted, when he look’d vpon the Tower,
As loth to beare me to the ſlaughter-houſe.
O now I need the Prieſt, that ſpake to me:
I now repent I told the Purſuiuant,
As too triumphing, how mine Enemies
To day at Pomfret bloodily were butcher’d,
And I my ſelfe ſecure, in grace and fauour.
Oh Margaret, Margaret, now thy heauie Curſe
Is lighted on poore Haſtings wretched Head.

speech.speaker: Ra.
speech.line: Come, come, diſpatch, the Duke would be at dinner:
Make a ſhort Shriﬅ, he longs to ſee your Head.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: O momentarie grace of mortall men,
Which we more hunt for, then the grace of God!
Who builds his hope in ayre of your good Lookes,
Liues like a drunken Sayler on a Maſt,
Readie with euery Nod to tumble downe,
Into the fatall Bowels of the Deepe.

speech.speaker: Lou.
speech.line: Come, come, diſpatch, ’tis bootleſſe to exclaime.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: O bloody Richard: miſerable England,
I prophecie the fearefull’ſt time to thee,
That euer wretched Age hath look’d vpon.
Come, lead me to the Block, beare him my Head,
They ſmile at me, who ſhortly ſhall be dead.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard, and Buckingham, in rotten Armour, maruellous ill-fauoured

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Come Couſin,
Canſt thou quake, and change thy colour,
Murther thy breath in middle of a word,
And then againe begin, and ſtop againe,
As if thou were diſtraught, and mad with terror?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Tut, I can counterfeit the deepe Tragedian,
Speake, and looke backe, and prie on euery ſide,
Tremble and ſtart at wagging of a Straw:
Intending deepe ſuſpition, gaſtly Lookes
Are at my ſeruice, like enforced Smiles;
And both are readie in their Ofﬁces,
At any time to grace my Stratagemes.
But what, is Catesby gone?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: He is, and ſee he brings the Maior along.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Lord Maior.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Looke to the Draw-Bridge there.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Hearke, a Drumme.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Catesby, o’re-looke the Walls.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Lord Maior, the reaſon we haue ſent.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Looke back, defend thee, here are Enemies.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: God and our Innocencie defend, and guard vs.

scene.stagedir: Enter Louell and Ratcliffe, with Haſtings Head.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Be patient, they are friends: Ratcliffe, and Louell.

speech.speaker: Louell.
speech.line: Here is the Head of that ignoble Traytor,
The dangerous and vnſuſpeed Haſtings.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: So deare I lou’d the man, that I muſt weepe:
I tooke him for the plaineſt harmeleſſe Creature,
That breath’d vpon the Earth, a Chriſtian.
Made him my Booke, wherein my Soule recorded
The Hiſtorie of all her ſecret thoughts.
So ſmooth he dawb’d his Vice with ſhew of Vertue,
That his apparant open Guilt omitted,
I meane, his Conuerſation with Shores Wife,
He liu’d from all attainder of ſuſpes.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Well, well, he was the couertſt ſheltred Traytor
That euer liu’d.
Would you imagine, or almoſt beleeue,
Wert not, that by great preſeruation
We liue to tell it, that the ſubtill Traytor
This day had plotted, in the Councell-Houſe,
To murther me, and my good Lord of Gloſter.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: Had he done ſo?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: What? thinke you we are Turkes, or Inﬁdels?
Or that we would, againſt the forme of Law,
Proceed thus raſhly in the Villaines death,
But that the extreme perill of the caſe,
The Peace of England, and our Perſons ſafetie,
Enforc’d vs to this Execution.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: Now faire befall you, he deſeru’d his death,
And your good Graces both haue well proceeded,
To warne falſe Traytors from the like Attempts.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: I neuer look’d for better at his hands,
Aﬅer he once fell in with Miſtreſſe Shore:
Yet had we not determin’d he ſhould dye,
Vntill your Lordſhip came to ſee his end,
Which now the louing haſte of theſe our friends,
Something againſt our meanings, haue preuented;
Becauſe, my Lord, I would haue had you heard
The Traytor ſpeake, and timorouſly confeſſe
The manner and the purpoſe of his Treaſons:
That you might well haue ſignify’d the ſame
Vnto the Citizens, who haply may
Miſconſter vs in him, and wayle his death.

speech.speaker: Ma.
speech.line: But, my good Lord, your Graces words ſhal ſerue,
As well as I had ſeene, and heard him ſpeake:
And dœ not doubt, right Noble Princes both,
But Ile acquaint our dutious Citizens
With all your iuſt proceedings in this caſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And to that end we wiſh’d your Lordſhip here,
T’ auoid the Cenſures of the carping World.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Which ſince you come too late of our intent,
Yet witneſſe what you heare we did intend:
And ſo, my good Lord Maior, we bid farwell.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Gœ aﬅer, aﬅer, Couſin Buckingham.
The Maior towards Guild-Hall hyes him in all poſte:
There, at your meeteſt vantage of the time,
Inferre the Baſtardie of Edwards Children:
Tell them, how Edward put to death a Citizen,
Onely for ſaying, he would make his Sonne
Heire to the Crowne, meaning indeed his Houſe,
Which, by the Signe thereof, was tearmed ſo.
Moreouer, vrge his hatefull Luxurie,
And beaſtiall appetite in change of Luſt,
Which ſtretcht vnto their Seruants, Daughters, Wiues,
Euen where his raging eye, or ſauage heart,
Without controll, luſted to make a prey.
Nay, for a need, thus farre come neere my Perſon:
Tell them, when that my Mother went with Child
Of that inſatiate Edward; Noble Yorke,
My Princely Father, then had Warres in France,
And by true computation of the time,
Found, that the Iſſue was not his begot:
Which well appeared in his Lineaments,
Being nothing like the Noble Duke, my Father:
Yet touch this ſparingly, as ’twere farre off,
Becauſe, my Lord, you know my Mother liues.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Doubt not, my Lord, Ile play the Orator,
As if the Golden Fee, for which I plead,
Were for my ſelfe: and ſo, my Lord, adue.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: If you thriue wel, bring them to Baynards Caſtle,
Where you ſhall ﬁnde me well accompanied
With reuerend Fathers, and well-learned Biſhops.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: I gœ, and towards three or foure a Clocke
Looke for the Newes that the Guild-Hall affoords.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Gœ Louell with all ſpeed to Door Shaw,
Gœ thou to Fryer Penker, bid them both
Meet me within this houre at Baynards Caſtle.
Now will I gœ to take ſome priuie order,
To draw the Brats of Clarence out of ſight,
And to giue order, that no manner perſon
Haue any time recourſe vnto the Princes.

speech.speaker: Scr.
speech.line: Here is the Indiment of the good Lord Haſtings,
Which in a ſet Hand fairely is engroſs’d,
That it may be to day read o’re in Paules.
And marke how well the ſequell hangs together:
Eleuen houres I haue ſpent to write it ouer,
For yeſter-night by Catesby was it ſent me,
The Precedent was full as long a doing,
And yet within theſe ﬁue houres Haſtings liu’d,
Vntainted, vnexamin’d, free, at libertie.
Here’s a good World the while.
Who is ſo groſſe, that cannot ſee this palpable deuice?
Yet who ſo bold, but ſayes he ſees it not?
Bad is the World, and all will come to nought,
When ſuch ill dealing muſt be ſeene in thought.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard and Buckingham at ſeuerall Doores.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: How now, how now, what ſay the Citizens?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Now by the holy Mother of our Lord,
The Citizens are mum, ſay not a word.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Toucht you the Baſtardie of Edwards Children?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: I did, with his Contra with Lady Lucy,
And his Contra by Deputie in France,
Th’ vnſatiate greedineſſe of his deſire,
And his enforcement of the Citie Wiues,
His Tyrannie for Triﬂes, his owne Baſtardie,
As being got, your Father then in France,
And his reſemblance, being not like the Duke.
Withall, I did inferre your Lineaments,
Being the right Idea of your Father,
Both in your forme, and Nobleneſſe of Minde:
Layd open all your Viories in Scotland,
Your Diſcipline in Warre, Wiſdome in Peace,
Your Bountie, Vertue, faire Humilitie:
Indeed, leﬅ nothing ﬁtting for your purpoſe,
Vntoucht, or ſleightly handled in diſcourſe.
And when my Oratorie drew toward end,
I bid them that did loue their Countries good,
Cry, God ſaue Richard, Englands Royall King.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And did they ſo?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: No, ſo God helpe me, they ſpake not a word,
But like dumbe Statues, or breathing Stones,
Star’d each on other, and look’d deadly pale:
Which when I ſaw, I reprehended them,
And ask’d the Maior, what meant this wilfull ſilence?
His anſwer was, the people were not vſed
To be ſpoke to, but by the Recorder.
Then he was vrg’d to tell my Tale againe:
Thus ſayth the Duke, thus hath the Duke inferr’d,
But nothing ſpoke, in warrant from himſelfe.
When he had done, ſome followers of mine owne,
At lower end of the Hall, hurld vp their Caps,
And ſome tenne voyces cry’d, God ſaue King Richard:
And thus I tooke the vantage of thoſe few.
Thankes gentle Citizens, and friends, quoth I,
This generall applauſe, and chearefull ſhowt,
Argues your wiſdome, and your loue to Richard:
And euen here brake off, and came away.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: What tongue-leſſe Blockes were they,
Would they not ſpeake?
Will not the Maior then, and his Brethren, come?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: The Maior is here at hand: intend ſome feare,
Be not you ſpoke with, but by mightie ſuit:
And looke you get a Prayer-Booke in your hand,
And ſtand betweene two Church-men, good my Lord,
For on that ground Ile make a holy Deſcant:
And be not eaſily wonne to our requeſts,
Play the Maids part, ſtill anſwer nay, and take it.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I gœ: and if you plead as well for them,
As I can ſay nay to thee for my ſelfe,
No doubt we bring it to a happie iſſue.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Go, go vp to the Leads, the Lord Maior knocks.
Welcome, my Lord, I dance attendance here,
I thinke the Duke will not be ſpoke withall.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Now Catesby, what ſayes your Lord to my
requeſt?

speech.speaker: Catesby.
speech.line: He doth entreat your Grace, my Noble Lord,
To viſit him to morrow, or next day:
He is within, with two right reuerend Fathers,
Diuinely bent to Meditation,
And in no Worldly ſuites would he be mou’d,
To draw him from his holy Exerciſe.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Returne, good Catesby, to the gracious Duke,
Tell him, my ſelfe, the Maior and Aldermen,
In deepe deſignes, in matter of great moment,
No leſſe importing then our generall good,
Are come to haue ſome conference with his Grace.

speech.speaker: Catesby
speech.line: Ile ſigniﬁe ſo much vnto him ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Ah ha, my Lord, this Prince is not an Edward,
He is not lulling on a lewd Loue-Bed,
But on his Knees, at Meditation:
Not dallying with a Brace of Curtizans,
But meditating with two deepe Diuines:
Not ſleeping, to engroſſe his idle Body,
But praying, to enrich his watchfull Soule.
Happie were England, would this vertuous Prince
Take on his Grace the Soueraigntie thereof.
But ſure I feare we ſhall not winne him to it.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: Marry God defend his Grace ſhould ſay vs
nay.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: I feare he will: here Catesby comes againe.
Now Catesby, what ſayes his Grace?

speech.speaker: Catesby.
speech.line: He wonders to what end you haue aſſembled
Such troopes of Citizens, to come to him,
His Grace not being warn’d thereof before:
He feares, my Lord, you meane no good to him.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Sorry I am, my Noble Couſin ſhould
Suſpe me, that I meane no good to him:
By Heauen, we come to him in perﬁt loue,
And ſo once more returne, and tell his Grace.
When holy and deuout Religious men
Are at their Beades, ’tis much to draw them thence,
So ſweet is zealous Contemplation.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard aloﬅ, betweene two Biſhops.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: See where his Grace ſtands, tweene two Clergie
men.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Two Props of Vertue, for a Chriſtian Prince,
To ſtay him from the fall of Vanitie:
And ſee a Booke of Prayer in his hand,
True Ornaments to know a holy man.
Famous Plantagenet, moſt gracious Prince,
Lend fauourable eare to our requeſts,
And pardon vs the interruption
Of thy Deuotion, and right Chriſtian Zeale.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: My Lord, there needes no ſuch Apologie:
I dœ beſeech your Grace to pardon me,
Who earneſt in the ſeruice of my God,
Deferr’d the viſitation of my friends.
But leauing this, what is your Graces pleaſure?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Euen that (I hope) which pleaſeth God aboue,
And all good men, of this vngouern’d Ile.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I dœ ſuſpe I haue done ſome offence,
That ſeemes diſgracious in the Cities eye,
And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: You haue, my Lord:
Would it might pleaſe your Grace,
On our entreaties, to amend your fault.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Elſe wherefore breathe I in a Chriſtian Land.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Know then, it is your fault, that you reſigne
The Supreme Seat, the Throne Maieſticall,
The Sceptred Ofﬁce of your Anceſtors,
Your State of Fortune, and your Deaw of Birth,
The Lineall Glory of your Royall Houſe,
To the corruption of a blemiſht Stock;
Whiles in the mildneſſe of your ſleepie thoughts,
Which here we waken to our Countries good,
The Noble Ile doth want his proper Limmes:
His Face defac’d with ſkarres of Infamie,
His Royall Stock grafﬅ with ignoble Plants,
And almoſt ſhouldred in the ſwallowing Gulfe
Of darke Forgetfulneſſe, and deepe Obliuion.
Which to recure, we heartily ſolicite
Your gracious ſelfe to take on you the charge
And Kingly Gouernment of this your Land:
Not as Proteor, Steward, Subſtitute,
Or lowly Faor, for anothers gaine;
But as ſucceſſiuely, from Blood to Blood,
Your Right of Birth, your Empyrie, your owne.
For this, conſorted with the Citizens,
Your very Worſhipfull and louing friends,
And by their vehement inſtigation,
In this iuſt Cauſe come I to moue your Grace.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I cannot tell, if to depart in ſilence,
Or bitterly to ſpeake in your reproofe,
beſt ﬁtteth my Degree, or your Condition.
If not to anſwer, you might haply thinke,
Tongue-ty’d Ambition, not replying, yeelded
To beare the Golden Yoake of Soueraigntie,
Which fondly you would here impoſe on me.
If to reproue you for this ſuit of yours,
So ſeaſon’d with your faithfull loue to me,
Then on the other ſide I check’d my friends.
Therefore to ſpeake, and to auoid the ﬁrſt,
And then in ſpeaking, not to incurre the laſt,
Deﬁnitiuely thus I anſwer you.
Your loue deſerues my thankes, but my deſert
Vnmeritable, ſhunnes your high requeſt.
Firſt, if all Obſtacles were cut away,
And that my Path were euen to the Crowne,
As the ripe Reuenue, and due of Birth:
Yet ſo much is my pouertie of ſpirit,
So mightie, and ſo manie my defes,
That I would rather hide me from my Greatneſſe,
Being a Barke to brooke no mightie Sea;
Then in my Greatneſſe couet to be hid,
And in the vapour of my Glory ſmother’d.
But God be thank’d, there is no need of me,
And much I need to helpe you, were there need:
The Royall Tree hath leﬅ vs Royall Fruit,
Which mellow’d by the ſtealing howres of time,
Will well become the Seat of Maieſtie,
And make (no doubt) vs happy by his Reigne.
On him I lay that, you would lay on me,
The Right and Fortune of his happie Starres,
Which God defend that I ſhould wring from him.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: My Lord, this argues Conſcience in your Grace,
But the reſpes thereof are nice, and triuiall,
All circumſtances well conſidered.
You ſay, that Edward is your Brothers Sonne,
So ſay we too, but not by Edwards Wife:
For ﬁrſt was he contra to Lady Lucie,
Your Mother liues a Witneſſe to his Vow;
And aﬅerward by ſubſtitute betroth’d
To Bona, Siſter to the King of France.
Theſe both put off, a poore Petitioner,
A Care-cras’d Mother to a many Sonnes,
A Beautie-waining, and diſtreſſed Widow,
Euen in the aﬅer-noone of her beſt dayes,
Made prize and purchaſe of his wanton Eye,
Seduc’d the pitch, and height of his degree,
To baſe declenſion, and loath’d Bigamie.
By her, in his vnlawfull Bed, he got
This Edward, whom our Manners call the Prince.
More bitterly could I expoſtulate,
Saue that for reuerence to ſome aliue,
I giue a ſparing limit to my Tongue.
Then good, my Lord, take to your Royall ſelfe
This proffer’d beneﬁt of Dignitie:
If not to bleſſe vs and the Land withall,
Yet to draw forth your Noble Anceſtrie
From the corruption of abuſing times,
Vnto a Lineall true deriued courſe.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: Do good my Lord, your Citizens entreat you.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Refuſe not, mightie Lord, this proffer’d loue.

speech.speaker: Catesb.
speech.line: O make them ioyfull, grant their lawfull ſuit.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Alas, why would you heape this Care on me?
I am vnﬁt for State, and Maieſtie:
I dœ beſeech you take it not amiſſe,
I cannot, nor I will not yeeld to you.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: If you refuſe it, as in loue and zeale,
Loth to depoſe the Child, your Brothers Sonne,
As well we know your tenderneſſe of heart,
And gentle, kinde, effeminate remorſe,
Which we haue noted in you to your Kindred,
And egally indeede to all Eſtates:
Yet know, where you accept our ſuit, or no,
Your Brothers Sonne ſhall neuer reigne our King,
But we will plant ſome other in the Throne,
To the diſgrace and downe-fall of your Houſe:
And in this reſolution here we leaue you.
Come Citizens, we will entreat no more.

speech.speaker: Catesb.
speech.line: Call him againe, ſweet Prince, accept their ſuit:
If you denie them, all the Land will rue it.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Will you enforce me to a world of Cares.
Call them againe, I am not made of Stones,
But penetrable to your kinde entreaties,
Albeit againſt my Conſcience and my Soule.
Couſin of Buckingham, and ſage graue men,
Since you will buckle fortune on my back,
To beare her burthen, where I will or no.
I muſt haue patience to endure the Load:
But if black Scandall, or foule-fac’d Reproach,
Attend the ſequell of your Impoſition,
Your meere enforcement ſhall acquittance me
From all the impure blots and ſtaynes thereof;
For God doth know, and you may partly ſee,
How farre I am from the deſire of this.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: God bleſſe your Grace, wee ſee it, and will
ſay it.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: In ſaying ſo, you ſhall but ſay the truth.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Then I ſalute you with this Royall Title,
Long liue King Richard, Englands worthie King.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: To morrow may it pleaſe you to be Crown’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Euen when you pleaſe, for you will haue it ſo.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: To morrow then we will attend your Grace,
And ſo moſt ioyfully we take our leaue.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Come, let vs to our holy Worke againe.
Farewell my Couſins, farewell gentle friends.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Queene, Anne Ducheſſe of Glouceſter, the Ducheſſe of Yorke, and Marqueſſe Dorſet

speech.speaker: Duch.Yorke.
speech.line: Who meetes vs heere?
My Neece Plantagenet,
Led in the hand of her kind Aunt of Gloſter?
Now, for my Life, ſhee’s wandring to the Tower,
On pure hearts loue, to greet the tender Prince.
Daughter, well met.

speech.speaker: Anne.
speech.line: God giue your Graces both, a happie
And a ioyfull time of day.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: As much to you, good Siſter: whither away?

speech.speaker: Anne.
speech.line: No farther then the Tower, and as I gueſſe,
Vpon the like deuotion as your ſelues,
To gratulate the gentle Princes there.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Kind Siſter thankes, wee’le enter all together:
And in good time, here the Lieutenant comes.
Maſter Lieutenant, pray you, by your leaue,
How doth the Prince, and my young Sonne of Yorke?

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Right well, deare Madame: by your patience,
I may not ſuffer you to viſit them,
The King hath ſtrily charg’d the contrary.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: The King? who’s that?

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: I meane, the Lord Proteor.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: The Lord prote him from that Kingly Title.
Hath he ſet bounds betweene their loue, and me?
I am their Mother, who ſhall barre me from them?

speech.speaker: Duch.Yorke.
speech.line: I am their Fathers Mother, I will ſee
them.

speech.speaker: Anne.
speech.line: Their Aunt I am in law, in loue their Mother:
Then bring me to their ſights, Ile beare thy blame,
And take thy Ofﬁce from thee, on my perill.

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: No, Madame, no; I may not leaue it ſo:
I am bound by Oath, and therefore pardon me.

speech.speaker: Stanley.
speech.line: Let me but meet you Ladies one howre hence,
And Ile ſalute your Grace of Yorke as Mother,
And reuerend looker on of two faire Queenes.
Come Madame, you muſt ſtraight to Weſtminſter,
There to be crowned Richards Royall Queene.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Ah, cut my Lace aſunder,
That my pent heart may haue ſome ſcope to beat,
Or elſe I ſwoone with this dead-killing newes.

speech.speaker: Anne.
speech.line: Deſpightfull tidings, O vnpleaſing newes.

speech.speaker: Dors.
speech.line: Be of good cheare: Mother, how fares your
Grace?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: O Dorſet, ſpeake not to me, get thee gone,
Death and Deſtruion dogges thee at thy heeles,
Thy Mothers Name is ominous to Children.
If thou wilt out-ſtrip Death, gœ croſſe the Seas,
And liue with Richmond, from the reach of Hell.
Gœ hye thee, hye thee from this ſlaughter-houſ,
Leſt thou encreaſe the number of the dead,
And make me dye the thrall of Margarets Curſe,
Nor Mother, Wife, nor Englands counted Queene.

speech.speaker: Stanley.
speech.line: Full of wiſe care, is this your counſaile, Madame:
Take all the ſwiﬅ aduantage of the howres:
You ſhall haue Letters from me to my Sonne,
In your behalfe, to meet you on the way:
Be not ta’ne tardie by vnwiſe delay.

speech.speaker: Duch.Yorke.
speech.line: O ill diſperſing Winde of Miſerie.
O my accurſed Wombe, the Bed of Death:
A Cockatrice haſt thou hatcht to the World,
Whoſe vnauoided Eye is murtherous.

speech.speaker: Stanley.
speech.line: Come, Madame, come, I in all haſte was ſent.

speech.speaker: Anne.
speech.line: And I with all vnwillingneſſe will gœ.
O would to God, that the incluſiue Verge
Of Golden Mettall, that muſt round my Brow,
Were red hot Steele, to ſeare me to the Braines,
Anoynted let me be with deadly Venome,
And dye ere men can ſay, God ſaue the Queene.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Gœ, gœ, poore ſoule, I enuie not thy glory,
To feed my humor, wiſh thy ſelfe no harme.

speech.speaker: Anne.
speech.line: No: why? When he that is my Husband now,
Came to me, as I follow’d Henries Corſe,
When ſcarce the blood was well waſht from his hands,
Which iſſued from my other Angell Husband,
And that deare Saint, which then I weeping follow’d:
O, when I ſay I look’d on Richard’s Face,
This was my Wiſh: Be thou (quoth I) accurſt,
For making me, ſo young, ſo old a Widow:
And when thou wed’ſt, let ſorrow haunt thy Bed;
And be thy Wife, if any be ſo mad,
More miſerable, by the Life of thee,
Then thou haſt made me, by my deare Lords death.
Lœ, ere I can repeat this Curſe againe,
Within ſo ſmall a time, my Womans heart
Groſſely grew captiue to his honey words,
And prou’d the ſubie of mine owne Soules Curſe,
Which hitherto hath held mine eyes from reſt:
For neuer yet one howre in his Bed
Did I enioy the golden deaw of ſleepe,
But with his timorous Dreames was ſtill awak’d.
Beſides, he hates me for my Father Warwicke,
And will (no doubt) ſhortly be rid of me.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Poore heart adieu, I pittie thy complaining.

speech.speaker: Anne.
speech.line: No more, then with my ſoule I mourne for
yours.

speech.speaker: Dors.
speech.line: Farewell, thou wofull welcommer of glory.

speech.speaker: Anne.
speech.line: Adieu, poore ſoule, that tak’ſt thy leaue
of it.

speech.speaker: Du.Y.
speech.line: Go thou to Richmond, & good fortune guide thee,
Go thou to Richard, and good Angels tend thee,
Go thou to Sanuarie, and good thoughts poſſeſſe thee,
I to my Graue, where peace and reſt lye with mee.
Eightie odde yeeres of ſorrow haue I ſeene,
And each howres ioy wrackt with a weeke of teene.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Stay, yet looke backe with me vnto the Tower.
Pitty, you ancient Stones, thoſe tender Babes,
Whom Enuie hath immur’d within your Walls,
Rough Cradle for ſuch little prettie ones,
Rude ragged Nurſe, old ſullen Play-fellow,
For tender Princes: vſe my Babies well;
So fooliſh Sorrowes bids your Stones farewell.

scene.stagedir: Sound a Sennet. Enter Richard in pompe, Buckingham, Catesby, Ratcliffe, Louel.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Stand all apart. Couſin of Buckingham.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: My gracious Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: Rich
speech.line: Giue me thy hand.
Thus high, by thy aduice, and thy aſſiſtance,
Is King Richard ſeated:
But ſhall we weare theſe Glories for a day?
Or ſhall they laſt, and we reioyce in them?

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Still liue they, and for euer let them laſt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ah Buckingham, now dœ I play the Touch,
To trie if thou be currant Gold indeed:
Young Edward liues, thinke now what I would ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Say on my louing Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why Buckingham, I ſay I would be King.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Why ſo you are, my thrice-renowned Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ha? am I King? ’tis ſo: but Edward liues.

speech.speaker: Buck
speech.line: True, Noble Prince.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: O bitter conſequence!
That Edward ſtill ſhould liue true Noble Prince.
Couſin, thou waſt not wont to be ſo dull.
Shall I be plaine? I wiſh the Baſtards dead,
And I would haue it ſuddenly perform’d.
What ſay’ſt thou now? ſpeake ſuddenly, be briefe.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: Your Grace may dœ your pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Tut, tut, thou art all Ice, thy kindneſſe freezes:
Say, haue I thy conſent, that they ſhall dye?

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Giue me ſome litle breath, ſome pawſe, deare Lord,
Before I poſitiuely ſpeake in this:
I will reſolue you herein preſently.

speech.speaker: Catesby.
speech.line: The King is angry, ſee he gnawes his Lippe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I will conuerſe with Iron-witted Fooles,
And vnreſpeiue Boyes: none are for me,
That looke into me with conſiderate eyes,
High-reaching Buckingham growes circumſpe.
Boy.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Know’ſt thou not any, whom corrupting Gold
Will tempt vnto a cloſe exploit of Death?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: I know a diſcontented Gentleman,
Whoſe humble meanes match not his haughtie ſpirit:
Gold were as good as twentie Orators,
And will (no doubt) tempt him to any thing.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: What is his Name?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: His Name, my Lord, is Tirrell.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I partly know the man: gœ call him hither,
Boy.
The deepe reuoluing wittie Buckingham,
No more ſhall be the neighbor to my counſailes.
Hath he ſo long held out with me, vntyr’d,
And ſtops he now for breath? Well, be it ſo.
How now, Lord Stanley, what’s the newes?

speech.speaker: Stanley.
speech.line: Know my louing Lord, the Marqueſſe Dorſet
As I heare, is ﬂed to Richmond,
In the parts where he abides.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Come hither Catesby, rumor it abroad,
That Anne my Wife is very grieuous ſicke,
I will take order for her keeping cloſe.
Inquire me out ſome meane poore Gentleman,
Whom I will marry ſtraight to Clarence Daughter:
The Boy is fooliſh, and I feare not him.
Looke how thou dream’ſt: I ſay againe, giue out,
That Anne, my Queene, is ſicke, and like to dye.
About it, for it ſtands me much vpon
To ſtop all hopes, whoſe growth may dammage me.
I muſt be marryed to my Brothers Daughter,
Or elſe my Kingdome ſtands on brittle Glaſſe:
Murther her Brothers, and then marry her,
Vncertaine way of gaine. But I am in
So farre in blood, that ſinne will pluck on ſinne,
Teare-falling Pittie dwells not in this Eye.
Is thy Name Tyrrel?

speech.speaker: Tyr.
speech.line: Iames Tyrrel, and your moſt obedient ſubie.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Art thou indeed?

speech.speaker: Tyr.
speech.line: Proue me, my gracious Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Dar’ſt thou reſolue to kill a friend of mine?

speech.speaker: Tyr.
speech.line: Pleaſe you:
But I had rather kill two enemies.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why then thou haſt it: two deepe enemies,
Fœs to my Reſt, and my ſweet ſleepes diſturbers,
Are they that I would haue thee deale vpon:
Tyrrel, I meane thoſe Baſtards in the Tower.

speech.speaker: Tyr.
speech.line: Let me haue open meanes to come to them,
And ſoone Ile rid you from the feare of them.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thou ſing’ſt ſweet Muſique:
Hearke, come hither Tyrrel,
Gœ by this token: riſe, and lend thine Eare,
There is no more but ſo: ſay it is done,
And I will loue thee, and preferre thee for it.

speech.speaker: Tyr.
speech.line: I will diſpatch it ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: My Lord, I haue conſider’d in my minde,
The late requeſt that you did ſound me in.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Well, let that reſt: Dorſet is ﬂed to Richmond.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: I heare the newes, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Stanley, hee is your Wiues Sonne: well, looke
vnto it.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: My Lord, I clayme the giﬅ, my due by promiſe,
For which your Honor and your Faith is pawn’d,
Th’ Earledome of Hertford, and the moueables,
Which you haue promiſed I ſhall poſſeſſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Stanley looke to your Wife: if ſhe conuey
Letters to Richmond, you ſhall anſwer it.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: What ſayes your Highneſſe to my iuſt requeſt?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I dœ remember me, Henry the Sixt
Did prophecie, that Richmond ſhould be King,
When Richmond was a little peeuiſh Boy.
A King perhaps.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: May it pleaſe you to reſolue me in my ſuit.

speech.speaker: Rich
speech.line: Thou troubleſt me, I am not in the vaine.

speech.speaker: Buck.
speech.line: And is it thus? repayes he my deepe ſeruice
With ſuch contempt? made I him King for this?
O let me thinke on Haſtings, and be gone
To Breenock, while my fearefull Head is on.

speech.speaker: Tyr.
speech.line: The tyrannous and bloodie A is done,
The moſt arch deed of pittious maſſacre
That euer yet this Land was guilty of:
Dighton and Forreſt, who I did ſuborne
To do this peece of ruthfull Butchery,
Albeit they were fleſht Villaines, bloody Dogges,
Melted with tenderneſſe, and milde compaſſion,
Wept like to Children, in their deaths ſad Story.
O thus (quoth Dighton) lay the gentle Babes:
Thus, thus (quoth Forreſt) girdling one another
Within their Alablaſter innocent Armes:
Their lips were foure red Roſes on a ſtalke,
And in their Summer Beauty kiſt each other.
A Booke of Prayers on their pillow lay,
Which one (quoth Forreſt) almoſt chang’d my minde:
But oh the Diuell, there the Villaine ſtopt:
When Dighton thus told on, we ſmothered
The moſt repleniſhed ſweet worke of Nature,
That from the prime Creation ere ſhe framed.
Hence both are gone with Conſcience and Remorſe,
They could not ſpeake, and ſo I leﬅ them both,
To beare this tydings to the bloody King.
And heere he comes. All health my Soueraigne Lord.

speech.speaker: Ric.
speech.line: Kinde Tirrell, am I happy in thy Newes.

speech.speaker: Tir.
speech.line: If to haue done the thing you gaue in charge,
Beget your happineſſe, be happy then,
For it is done.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: But did’ſt thou ſee them dead.

speech.speaker: Tir.
speech.line: I did my Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And buried gentle Tirrell.

speech.speaker: Tir.
speech.line: The Chaplaine of the Tower hath buried them,
But where (to ſay the truth) I do not know.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Come to me Tirrel ſoone, and aﬅer Supper,
When thou ſhalt tell the proceſſe of their death.
Meane time, but thinke how I may do the good,
And be inheritor of thy deſire.
Farewell till then.

speech.speaker: Tir.
speech.line: I humbly take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Sonne of Clarence haue I pent vp cloſe,
His daughter meanly haue I matcht in marriage,
The Sonnes of Edward ſleepe in Abrahams boſome,
And Anne my wife hath bid this world good night.
Now for I know the Britaine Richmond aymes
At yong Elizabeth my brothers daughter,
And by that knot lookes proudly on the Crowne,
To her go I, a iolly thriuing woœr.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Good or bad newes, that thou com’ſt in ſo
bluntly?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Bad news my Lord, Mourton is ﬂed to Richmond,
And Buckingham backt with the hardy Welſhmen
Is in the ﬁeld, and ſtill his power encreaſeth.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ely with Richmond troubles me more neere,
Then Buckingham and his raſh leuied Strength.
Come, I haue learn’d, that fearfull commenting
Is leaden ſeruitor to dull delay.
Delay leds impotent and Snaile-pac’d Beggery:
Then ﬁerie expedition be my wing,
Ioues Mercury, and Herald for a King:
Go muſter men: My counſaile is my Sheeld,
We muſt be breefe, when Traitors braue the Field.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: So now proſperity begins to mellow,
And drop into the rotten mouth of death:
Heere in theſe Conﬁnes ſlily haue I lurkt,
To watch the waining of mine enemies.
A dire induion, am I witneſſe to,
And will to France, hoping the conſequence
Will proue as bitter, blacke, and Tragicall.
Withdraw thee wretched Margaret, who comes heere?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Ah my poore Princes! ah my tender Babes:
My vnblowed Flowres, new appearing ſweets:
If yet your gentle ſoules ﬂye in the Ayre,
And be not ﬁxt in doome perpetuall,
Houer about me with your ayery wings,
And heare your mothers Lamentation.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Houer about her, ſay that right for right
Hath dim’d your Infant morne, to Aged night.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: So many miſeries haue craz’d my voyce,
That my wœ-wearied tongue is ſtill and mute.
Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet,
Edward for Edward, payes a dying debt.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Wilt thou, O God, ﬂye from ſuch gentle Lambs,
And throw them in the intrailes of the Wolfe?
When didſt thou ſleepe, when ſuch a deed was done?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: When holy Harry dyed, and my ſweet Sonne.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Dead life, blind ſight, poore mortall liuing ghoſt,
Wœs Scene, Worlds ſhame, Graues due, by life vſurpt,
Breefe abſtra and record of tedious dayes,
Reſt thy vnreſt on Englands lawfull earth,
Vnlawfully made drunke with innocent blood.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Ah that thou would’ſt aſſoone affoord a Graue,
As thou canſt yeeld a melancholly ſeate:
Then would I hide my bones, not reſt them heere,
Ah who hath any cauſe to mourne but wee?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: If ancient ſorrow be moſt reuerent,
Giue mine the beneﬁt of ſigneurie,
And let my greefes frowne on the vpper hand
If ſorrow can admit Society.
I had an Edward, till a Richard kill’d him:
I had a Husband, till a Richard kill’d him:
Thou had’ſt an Edward, till a Richard kill’d him:
Thou had’ſt a Richard, till a Richard kill’d him.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: I had a Richard too, and thou did’ſt kill him;
I had a Rutland too, thou hop’ſt to kill him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Thou had’ſt a Clarence too,
And Richard kill’d him.
From forth the kennell of thy wombe hath crept
A Hell-hound that doth hunt vs all to death:
That Dogge, that had his teeth before his eyes,
To worry Lambes, and lap their gentle blood:
That foule defacer of Gods handy worke:
That reignes in gauled eyes of weeping ſoules:
That excellent grand Tyrant of the earth,
Thy wombe let looſe to chaſe vs to our graues.
O vpright, iuſt, and true-diſpoſing God,
How do I thanke thee, that this carnall Curre
Prayes on the iſſue of his Mothers body,
And makes her Pue-fellow with others mone.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Oh Harries wife, triumph not in my wœs:
God witneſſe with me, I haue wept for thine.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Beare with me: I am hungry for reuenge,
And now I cloy me with beholding it.
Thy Edward he is dead, that kill’d my Edward,
The other Edward dead, to quit my Edward:
Yong Yorke, he is but boote, becauſe both they
Matcht not the high perfeion of my loſſe.
Thy Clarence he is dead, that ſtab’d my Edward,
And the beholders of this franticke play,
Th’ adulterate Haſtings, Riuers, Vaughan, Gray,
Vntimely ſmother’d in their duſky Graues.
Richard yet liues, Hels blacke Intelligencer,
Onely reſeru’d their Faor, to buy ſoules,
And ſend them thither: But at hand, at hand
Inſues his pittious and vnpittied end.
Earth gapes, Hell burnes, Fiends roare, Saints pray,
To haue him ſodainly conuey’d from hence:
Cancell his bond of life, deere God I pray,
That I may liue and ſay, The Dogge is dead.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: O thou did’ſt propheſie, the time would come,
That I ſhould wiſh for thee to helpe me curſe
That bottel’d Spider, that foule bunch-back’d Toad.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I call’d thee then, vaine ﬂouriſh of my fortune:
I call’d thee then, poore Shadow, painted Queen,
The preſentation of but what I was;
The ﬂattering Index of a direfull Pageant;
One heau’d a high, to be hurl’d downe below:
A Mother onely mockt with two faire Babes;
A dreame of what thou waſt, a gariſh Flagge
To be the ayme of euery dangerous Shot;
A ſigne of Dignity, a Breath, a Bubble;
A Queene in ieaſt, onely to ﬁll the Scene.
Where is thy Husband now? Where be thy Brothers?
Where be thy two Sonnes? Wherein doſt thou Ioy?
Who ſues, and kneeles, and ſayes, God ſaue the Queene?
Where be the bending Peeres that ﬂattered thee?
Where be the thronging Troopes that followed thee?
Decline all this, and ſee what now thou art.
For happy Wife, a moſt diſtreſſed Widdow:
For ioyfull Mother, one that wailes the name:
For one being ſued too, one that humbly ſues:
For Queene, a very Caytiffe, crown’d with care:
For ſhe that ſcorn’d at me, now ſcorn’d of me:
For ſhe being feared of all, now fearing one:
For ſhe commanding all, obey’d of none.
Thus hath the courſe of iuſtice whirl’d about,
And leﬅ thee but a very prey to time,
Hauing no more but Thought of what thou waſt.
To torture thee the more, being what thou art,
Thou didſt vſurpe my place, and doſt thou not
Vsurpe the iuſt proportion of my Sorrow?
Now thy proud Necke, beares halfe my burthen’d yoke,
From which, euen heere I ſlip my wearied head,
And leaue the burthen of it all, on thee.
Farwell Yorkes wife, and Queene of ſad miſchance,
theſe Engliſh wœs, ſhall make me ſmile in France.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: O thou well skill’d in Curſes, ſtay a-while,
And teach me how to Curſe mine enemies.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Forbeare to ſleepe the night, and faſt the day:
Compare dead happineſſe, with liuing wœ:
Thinke that thy Babes were ſweeter then they were,
And he that ſlew them fowler then he is:
Bett’ring thy loſſe, makes the bad cauſer worſe,
Reuoluing this, will teach thee how to Curſe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: My words are dull, O quicken them with thine.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Thy wœs will make them ſharpe,
And pierce like mine.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Why ſhould calamity be full of words?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Windy Atturnies to their Clients Wœs,
Ayery ſucceeders of inteſtine ioyes,
Poore breathing Orators of miſeries,
Let them haue ſcope, though what they will impart,
Helpe nothing els, yet do they eaſe the hart.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: If ſo then, be not Tongue-ty’d: go with me,
And in the breath of bitter words, let’s ſmother
My damned Son, that thy two ſweet Sonnes ſmother’d.
The Trumpet ſounds, be copious in exclaimes.

scene.stagedir: Enter King Richard, and his Traine.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Who intercepts me in my Expedition?

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: O ſhe, that might haue intercepted thee
By ſtrangling thee in her accurſed wombe,
From all the ſlaughters (Wretch) that thou haſt done.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Hid’ſt thou that Forhead with a Golden Crowne
Where’t ſhould be branded, if that right were right?
The ſlaughter of the Prince that ow’d that Crowne,
And the dyre death of my poore Sonnes, and Brothers.
Tell me thou Villaine-ſlaue, where are my Children?

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Thou Toad, thou Toade,
Where is thy Brother Clarence?
And little Ned Plantagenet his Sonne?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Where is the gentle Riuers, Vaughan, Gray?

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Where is kinde Haſtings?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: A ﬂouriſh Trumpets, ſtrike Alarum Drummes:
Let not the Heauens heare theſe Tell-tale women
Raile on the Lords Annointed. Strike I ſay.
Either be patient, and intreat me fayre,
Or with the clamorous report of Warre,
Thus will I drowne your exclamations.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Art thou my Sonne?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, I thanke God, my Father, and your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Then patiently heare my impatience.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Madam, I haue a touch of your condition,
That cannot brooke the accent of reproofe.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: O let me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Do then, but Ile not heare.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: I will be milde, and gentle in my words.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And breefe (good Mother) for I am in haſt.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Art thou ſo haſty? I haue ſtaid for thee
(God knowes) in torment and in agony.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And came I not at laſt to comfort you?

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: No by the holy Rood, thou know’ſt it well,
Thou cam’ſt on earth, to make the earth my Hell.
A greeuous burthen was thy Birth to me,
Tetchy and wayward was thy Infancie.
Thy School-daies frightfull, deſp’rate, wilde, and furious,
Thy prime of Manhood, daring, bold, and venturous:
Thy Age conﬁrm’d, proud, ſubtle, ſlye, and bloody,
More milde, but yet more harmfull; Kinde in hatred:
What comfortable houre canſt thou name,
That euer grac’d me with thy company?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Faith none, but Humfrey Hower,
That call’d your Grace
To Breakefaſt once, forth of my company.
If I be ſo diſgracious in your eye,
Let me march on, and not offend you Madam.
Strike vp the Drumme.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: I prythee heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: You ſpeake too bitterly.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Heare me a word:
For I ſhall neuer ſpeake to thee againe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: So.

speech.speaker: Dut.
speech.line: Either thou wilt dye, by Gods iuſt ordinance
Ere from this warre thou turne a Conqueror:
Or I with greefe and extreame Age ſhall periſh,
And neuer more behold thy face againe.
Therefore take with thee my moſt greeuous Curſe,
Which in the day of Battell tyre thee more
Then all the compleat Armour that thou wear’ſt.
My Prayers on the aduerſe party ﬁght,
And there the little ſoules of Edwards Children,
Whiſper the Spirits of thine Enemies,
And promiſe them Succeſſe and Viory:
Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end:
Shame ſerues thy life, and doth thy death attend.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Though far more cauſe, yet much leſſe ſpirit to curſe
Abides in me, I ſay Amen to her.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Stay Madam, I muſt talke a word with you.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: I haue no more ſonnes of the Royall Blood
For thee to ſlaughter. For my Daughters ( Richard)
They ſhall be praying Nunnes, not weeping Queenes:
And therefore leuell not to hit their liues.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: You haue a daughter call’d Elizabeth,
Vertuous and Faire, Royall and Gracious?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: And muſt ſhe dye for this? O let her liue,
And Ile corrupt her Manners, ſtaine her Beauty,
Slander my Selfe, as falſe to Edwards bed:
Throw ouer her the vaile of Infamy,
So ſhe may liue vnſcarr’d of bleeding ſlaughter,
I will confeſſe ſhe was not Edwards daughter.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Wrong not her Byrth, ſhe is a Royall Princeſſe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: To ſaue her life, Ile ſay ſhe is not ſo.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Her life is ſafeſt onely in her byrth.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: And onely in that ſafety, dyed her Brothers.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Lœ at their Birth, good ſtarres were oppoſite.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: No, to their liues, ill friends were contrary.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: All vnauoyded is the doome of Deſtiny.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: True: when auoyded grace makes Deſtiny.
My Babes were deſtin’d to a fairer death,
If grace had bleſt thee with a fairer life.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: You ſpeake as if that I had ſlaine my Coſins?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Coſins indeed, and by their Vnckle couzend,
Of Comfort, Kingdome, Kindred, Freedome, Life,
whoſe hand ſœuer lanch’d their tender hearts,
Thy head (all indirely) gaue direion.
No doubt the murd’rous Knife was dull and blunt,
Till it was whetted on thy ſtone-hard heart,
To reuell in the Intrailes of my Lambes.
But that ſtill vſe of greefe, makes wilde greefe tame,
My tongue ſhould to thy eares not name my Boyes,
Till that my Nayles were anchor’d in thine eyes:
And I in ſuch a deſp’rate Bay of death,
Like a poore Barke, of ſailes and tackling reﬅ,
Ruſh all to peeces on thy Rocky boſome.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Madam, ſo thriue I in my enterprize
And dangerous ſucceſſe of bloody warres,
As I intend more good to you and yours,
Then euer you and yours by me were harm’d.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: What good is couer’d with the face of heauen,
To be diſcouered, that can do me good.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Th’ aduancement of your children, gentle Lady

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Vp to ſome Scaffold, there to loſe their heads.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Vnto the dignity and height of Fortune,
The high Imperiall Type of this earths glory.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Flatter my ſorrow with report of it:
Tell me, what State, what Dignity, what Honor,
Canſt thou demiſe to any childe of mine.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Euen all I haue; I, and my ſelfe and all,
Will I withall indow a childe of thine:
So in the Lethe of thy angry ſoule,
Thou drowne the ſad remembrance of thoſe wrongs,
Which thou ſuppoſeſt I haue done to thee.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Be breefe, leaſt that the proceſſe of thy kindneſſe
laſt longer telling then thy kindneſſe date.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then know,
That from my Soule, I loue thy Daughter.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: My daughters Mother thinkes it with her ſoule.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: What do you thinke?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: That thou doſt loue my daughter from thy ſoule
So from thy Soules loue didſt thou loue her Brothers,
And from my hearts loue, I do thanke thee for it.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Be not ſo haſty to confound my meaning:
I meane that with my Soule I loue thy daughter,
And do intend to make her Queene of England.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Well then, who doſt ӳ meane ſhallbe her King.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Euen he that makes her Queene:
Who elſe ſhould bee?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: What, thou?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Euen ſo: How thinke you of it?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: How canſt thou woo her?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: That I would learne of you,
As one being beſt acquainted with her humour.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: And wilt thou learne of me?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Madam, with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Send to her by the man that ſlew her Brothers.
A paire of bleeding hearts: thereon ingraue
Edward and Yorke, then haply will ſhe weepe:
Therefore preſent to her, as ſometime Margaret
Did to thy Father, ſteept in Rutlands blood,
A hand-kercheefe, which ſay to her did dreyne
The purple ſappe from her ſweet Brothers body,
And bid her wipe her weeping eyes withall.
If this inducement moue her not to loue,
Send her a Letter of thy Noble deeds:
Tell her, thou mad’ſt away her Vnckle Clarence,
Her Vnckle Riuers, I (and for her ſake)
Mad’ſt quicke conueyance with her good Aunt Anne.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: You mocke me Madam, this not the way
To win your daughter.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: There is no other way,
Vnleſſe thou could’ſt put on ſome other ſhape,
And not be Richard, that hath done all this.

speech.speaker: Ric.
speech.line: Say that I did all this for loue of her.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Nay then indeed ſhe cannot chooſe but hate thee
Hauing bought loue, with ſuch a bloody ſpoyle.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Looke what is done, cannot be now amended:
Men ſhall deale vnaduiſedly ſometimes,
Which aﬅer-houres giues leyſure to repent.
If I did take the Kingdome from your Sonnes,
To make amends, Ile giue it to your daughter:
If I haue kill’d the iſſue of your wombe,
To quicken your encreaſe, I will beget
Mine yſſue of your blood, vpon your Daughter:
A Grandams name is little leſſe in loue,
Then is the doting Title of a Mother;
They are as Children but one ſteppe below,
Euen of your mettall, of your very blood:
Of all one paine, ſaue for a night of groanes
Endur’d of her, for whom you bid like ſorrow.
Your Children were vexation to your youth,
But mine ſhall be a comfort to your Age,
The loſſe you haue, is but a Sonne being King,
And by that loſſe, your Daughter is made Queene.
I cannot make you what amends I would,
Therefore accept ſuch kindneſſe as I can.
Dorſet your Sonne, that with a fearfull ſoule
Leads diſcontented ſteppes in Forraine ſoyle,
This faire Alliance, quickly ſhall call home
To high Promotions, and great Dignity.
The King that calles your beauteous Daughter Wife,
Familiarly ſhall call thy Dorſet, Brother:
Againe ſhall you be Mother to a King:
And all the Ruines of diſtreſſefull Times,
Repayr’d with double Riches of Content.
What? we haue many goodly dayes to ſee:
The liquid drops of Teares that you haue ſhed,
Shall come againe, transform’d to Orient Pearle,
Aduantaging their Loue, with intereſt
Oﬅen-times double gaine of happineſſe.
Go then (my Mother) to thy Daughter go,
Make bold her baſhfull yeares, with your experience,
Prepare her eares to heare a Wœrs Tale.
Put in her tender heart, th’ aſpiring Flame
Of Golden Soueraignty: Acquaint the Princeſſe
With the ſweet ſilent houres of Marriage ioyes:
And when this Arme of mine hath chaſtiſed
The petty Rebell, dull-brain’d Buckingham,
Bound with Triumphant Garlands will I come,
And leade thy daughter to a Conquerors bed:
To whom I will retaile my Conqueſt wonne,
And ſhe ſhalbe ſole Vioreſſe, Cæſars Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: What were I beſt to ſay, her Fathers Brother
Would be her Lord? Or ſhall I ſay her Vnkle?
Or he that ſlew her Brothers, and her Vnkles?
Vnder what Title ſhall I woo for thee,
That God, the Law, my Honor, and her Loue,
Can make ſeeme pleaſing to her tender yeares?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Inferre faire Englands peace by this Alliance.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Which ſhe ſhall purchaſe with ſtil laſting warre.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Tell her, the King that may command, intreats.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: That at her hands, which the kings King forbids.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Say ſhe ſhall be a High and Mighty Queene.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: To vaile the Title, as her Mother doth.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Say I will loue her euerlaſtingly.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: But how long ſhall that title euer laſt?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Sweetly in force, vnto her faire liues end.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: But how long fairely ſhall her ſweet life laſt?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: As long as Heauen and Nature lengthens it.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: As long as Hell and Richard likes of it.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Say, I her Soueraigne, am her Subie low.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: But ſhe your Subie, lothes ſuch Soueraignty.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Be eloquent in my behalfe to her.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: An honeſt tale ſpeeds beſt, being plainly told.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then plainly to her, tell my louing tale.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Plaine and not honeſt, is too harſh a ſtyle.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Your reaſons are too ſhallow, and to quicke.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: O no, my Reaſons are too deepe and dead,
Too deepe and dead (poore Infants) in their graues,
Harpe on it ſtill ſhall I, till heart-ſtrings breake.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Harpe not on that ſtring Madam, that is paſt.
Now by my George, my Garter, and my Crowne.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Prophan’d, diſhonor’d, and the third vſurpt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I ſweare.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: By nothing, for this is no Oath:
Thy George prophan’d, hath loſt his Lordly Honor;
Thy Garter blemiſh’d, pawn’d his Knightly Vertue;
Thy Crowne vſurp’d, diſgrac’d his Kingly Glory:
If ſomething thou would’ſt ſweare to be beleeu’d,
Sweare then by ſomething, that thou haſt not wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then by my Selfe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Thy Selfe, is ſelfe-miſvs’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Now by the World.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: ’Tis full of thy foule wrongs.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: My Fathers death.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Thy life hath it diſhonor’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why then, by Heauen.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Heauens wrong is moſt of all:
If thou didd’ſt feare to breake an Oath with him,
The vnity the King my husband made,
Thou had’ſt not broken, nor my Brothers died.
If thou had’ſt fear’d to breake an oath by him,
Th’ Imperiall mettall, circling now thy head,
Had grac’d the tender temples of my Child,
And both the Princes had bene breathing heere,
Which now two tender Bed-fellowes for duſt,
Thy broken Faith hath made the prey for Wormes.
What can’ſt thou ſweare by now.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The time to come.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: That thou haſt wronged in the time ore-paſt:
For I my ſelfe haue many teares to waſh
Heereaﬅer time, for time paſt, wrong’d by thee.
The Children liue, whoſe Fathers thou haſt ſlaughter’d,
Vngouern’d youth, to waile it with their age:
The Parents liue, whoſe Children thou haſt butcher’d,
Old barren Plants, to waile it with their Age.
Sweare not by time to come, for that thou haſt
Miſvs’d ere vs’d, by times ill-vs’d repaſt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: As I entend to proſper, and repent:
So thriue I in my dangerous Affayres
Of hoſtile Armes: My ſelfe, my ſelfe confound:
Heauen, and Fortune barre me happy houres:
Day, yeeld me not thy light; nor Night, thy reſt.
Be oppoſite all Planets of good lucke
To my proceeding, if with deere hearts loue,
Immaculate deuotion, holy thoughts,
I tender not thy beautious Princely daughter.
In her, conſiſts my Happineſſe, and thine:
Without her, followes to my ſelfe, and thee;
Her ſelfe, the Land, and many a Chriſtian ſoule,
Death, Deſolation, Ruine, and Decay:
It cannot be auoyded, but by this:
It will not be auoyded, but by this.
Therefore deare Mother (I muſt call you ſo)
Be the Atturney of my loue to her:
Pleade what I will be, not what I haue beene;
Not my deſerts, but what I will deſerue:
Vrge the Neceſſity and ſtate of times,
And be not peeuiſh found, in great Deſignes.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Shall I be tempted of the Diuel thus?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, if the Diuell tempt you to do good.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Shall I forget my ſelfe, to be my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, if your ſelfes remembrance wrong your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Yet thou didſt kil my Children.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: But in your daughters wombe I bury them.
Where in that Neſt of Spicery they will breed
Selues of themſelues, to your recomforture.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And be a happy Mother by the deed.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: I go, write to me very ſhortly,
And you ſhal vnderſtand from me her mind.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Beare her my true loues kiſſe, and ſo farewell.
Relenting Foole, and ſhallow-changing Woman.
How now, what newes?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Moſt mightie Soueraigne, on the Weſterne Coaſt
Rideth a puiſſant Nauie: to our Shores
Throng many doubtfull hollow-hearted friends,
Vnarm’d, and vnreſolu’d to beat them backe.
’Tis thought, that Richmond is their Admirall:
And there they hull, expeing but the aide
Of Buckingham, to welcome them aſhore.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Some light-foot friend post to ӳ Duke of Norfolk:
