Ratcliffe thy ſelfe, or Catesby, where is hee?

speech.speaker: Cat.
speech.line: Here, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Catesby, ﬂye to the Duke.

speech.speaker: Cat.
speech.line: I will, my Lord, with all conuenient haſte.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Catesby come hither, poſte to Salisbury:
When thou com’ſt thither: Dull vnmindfull Villaine,
Why ſtay’ſt thou here, and go’ſt not to the Duke?

speech.speaker: Cat.
speech.line: Firſt, mighty Liege, tell me your Highneſſe pleaſure,
What from your Grace I ſhall deliuer to him.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: O true, good Catesby, bid him leuie ſtraight
The greateſt ſtrength and power that he can make,
And meet me ſuddenly at Salisbury.

speech.speaker: Cat
speech.line: I gœ.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: What, may it pleaſe you, ſhall I dœ at Salis —
bury?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why, what would’ſt thou dœ there, before I
gœ?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Your Highneſſe told me I ſhould poſte before.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: My minde is chang’d:
Stanley, what newes with you?

speech.speaker: Sta.
speech.line: None, good my Liege, to pleaſe you with ý hearing,
Nor none ſo bad, but well may be reported.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Hoyday, a Riddle, neither good nor bad:
What need’ſt thou runne ſo many miles about,
When thou mayeſt tell thy Tale the neereſt way?
Once more, what newes?

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: Richmond is on the Seas.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: There let him ſinke, and be the Seas on him,
White-liuer’d Runnagate, what doth he there?

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: I know not, mightie Soueraigne, but by gueſſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Well, as you gueſſe.

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: Stirr’d vp by Dorſet, Buckingham, and Morton,
He makes for England, here to clayme the Crowne.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Is the Chayre emptie? is the Sword vnſway’d?
Is the King dead? the Empire vnpoſſeſt?
What Heire of Yorke is there aliue, but wee?
And who is Englands King, but great Yorkes Heire?
Then tell me, what makes he vpon the Seas?

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: Vnleſſe for that, my Liege, I cannot gueſſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Vnleſſe for that he comes to be your Liege,
You cannot gueſſe wherefore the Welchman comes.
Thou wilt reuolt, and ﬂye to him, I feare.

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: No, my good Lord, therefore miſtruſt me not.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Where is thy Power then, to beat him back?
Where be thy Tenants, and thy followers?
Are they not now vpon the Weſterne Shore,
Safe-conduing the Rebels from their Shippes?

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: No, my good Lord, my friends are in the
North.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Cold friends to me: what do they in the North,
When they ſhould ſerue their Soueraigne in the Weſt?

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: They haue not been commanded, mighty King:
Pleaſeth your Maieſtie to giue me leaue,
Ile muſter vp my friends, and meet your Grace,
Where, and what time your Maieſtie ſhall pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, thou would’ſt be gone, to ioyne with Richmond:
But Ile not truſt thee.

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: Moſt mightie Soueraigne,
You haue no cauſe to hold my friendſhip doubtfull,
I neuer was, nor neuer will be falſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Gœ then, and muſter men: but leaue behind
Your Sonne George Stanley: looke your heart be ﬁrme,
Or elſe his Heads aſſurance is but fraile.

speech.speaker: Stan.
speech.line: So deale with him, as I proue true to you.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: My gracious Soueraigne, now in Deuonſhire,
As I by friends am well aduertiſed,
Sir Edward Courtney, and the haughtie Prelate,
Biſhop of Exeter, his elder Brother,
With many mœ Confederates, are in Armes.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: In Kent, my Liege, the Guilfords are in Armes,
And euery houre more Competitors
Flocke to the Rebels, and their power growes ſtrong.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: My Lord, the Armie of great Buckingham.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Out on ye, Owles, nothing but Songs of Death,
There, take thou that, till thou bring better newes.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: The newes I haue to tell your Maieſtie,
Is, that by ſudden Floods, and fall of Waters,
Buckinghams Armie is diſpers’d and ſcatter’d,
And he himſelfe wandred away alone,
No man knowes whither.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I cry thee mercie:
There is my Purſe, to cure that Blow of thine.
Hath any well-aduiſed friend proclaym’d
Reward to him that brings the Traytor in?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Such Proclamation hath been made, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Sir Thomas Louell, and Lord Marqueſſe Dorſet,
’Tis ſaid, my Liege, in Yorkeſhire are in Armes:
But this good comfort bring I to your Highneſſe,
The Brittaine Nauie is diſpers’d by Tempeſt.
Richmond in Dorſetſhire ſent out a Boat
Vnto the ſhore, to aske thoſe on the Banks,
If they were his Aſſiſtants, yea, or no?
Who anſwer’d him, they came from Buckingham,
Vpon his partie: he miſtruſting them,
Hoys’d ſayle, and made his courſe againe for Brittaine.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: March on, march on, ſince we are vp in Armes,
If not to ﬁght with forraine Enemies,
Yet to beat downe theſe Rebels here at home.

speech.speaker: Cat.
speech.line: My Liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken,
That is the beſt newes: that the Earle of Richmond
Is with a mighty power Landed at Milford,
Is colder Newes, but yet they muſt be told.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Away towards Salsbury, while we reaſon here,
A Royall battell might be wonne and loſt:
Some one take order Buckingham be brought
To Salsbury, the reſt march on with me.

speech.speaker: Der.
speech.line: Sir Chriſtopher, tell Richmond this from me,
That in the ſtye of the moſt deadly Bore,
My Sonne George Stanley is frankt vp in hold:
If I reuolt, off gœs yong Georges head,
The feare of that, holds off my preſent ayde.
So get thee gone: commend me to thy Lord.
Withall ſay, that the Queene hath heartily conſented
He ſhould eſpouſe Elizabeth hir daughter.
But tell me, where is Princely Richmond now?

speech.speaker: Chri.
speech.line: At Penbroke, or at Hertford Weſt in Wales.

speech.speaker: Der.
speech.line: What men of Name reſort to him.

speech.speaker: Chri.
speech.line: Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned Souldier,
Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley,
Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir Iames Blunt,
And Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant Crew,
And many other of great name and worth:
And towards London do they bend their power,
If by the way they be not fought withall.

speech.speaker: Der.
speech.line: Well hye thee to thy Lord: I kiſſe his hand,
My Letter will reſolue him of my minde.
Farewell.

scene.stagedir: Enter Buckingham with Halberds, led to Execution.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Will not King Richard let me ſpeake with him?

speech.speaker: Sher.
speech.line: No my good Lord, therefore be patient.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Haſtings, and Edwards children, Gray & Riuers,
Holy King Henry, and thy faire Sonne Edward,
Vaughan, and all that haue miſcarried
By vnder-hand corrupted foule iniuſtice,
If that your moody diſcontented ſoules,
Do through the clowds behold this preſent houre,
Euen for reuenge mocke my deſtruion.
This is All-ſoules day (Fellow) is it not?

speech.speaker: Sher.
speech.line: It is.

speech.speaker: Buc.
speech.line: Why then Al-ſoules day, is my bodies doomſday
This is the day, which in King Edwards time
I wiſh’d might fall on me, when I was found
falſe to his Children, and his Wiues Allies.
This is the day, wherein I wiſht to fall
By the falſe Faith of him whom moſt I truſted.
This, this All-ſoules day to my fearfull Soule,
Is the determin’d reſpit of my wrongs:
That high All-ſeer, which I dallied with,
Hath turn’d my fained Prayer on my head,
And giuen in earneſt, what I begg’d in ieſt.
Thus doth he force the ſwords of wicked men
To turne their owne points in their Maſters boſomes.
Thus Margarets curſe falles heauy on my necke:
When he (quoth ſhe) ſhall ſplit thy heart with ſorrow,
Remember Margaret was a Propheteſſe:
Come leade me Ofﬁcers to the blocke of ſhame,
Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richmond, Oxford, Blunt, Herbert, and others, with drum and colours.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: Fellowes in Armes, and my moſt louing Frends
Bruis’d vnderneath the yoake of Tyranny,
Thus farre into the bowels of the Land,
Haue we marcht on without impediment;
And heere receiue we from our Father Stanley
Lines of faire comfort and encouragement:
The wretched, bloody, and vſurping Boare,
(That ſpoyl’d your Summer Fields, and fruitfull Vines)
Swilles your warm blood like waſh, & makes his trough
In your embowel’d boſomes: This foule Swine
Is now euen in the Centry of this Iſle,
Ne’re to the Towne of Leiceſter, as we learne:
From Tamworth thither, is but one dayes march.
In Gods name cheerely on, couragious Friends,
To reape the Harueſt of perpetuall peace,
By this one bloody tryall of ſharpe Warre.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Euery mans Conſcience is a thouſand men,
To ﬁght againſt this guilty Homicide.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: I doubt not but his Friends will turne to vs.

speech.speaker: Blunt.
speech.line: He hath no friends, but what are friends for fear,
Which in his deereſt neede will ﬂye from him.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: All for our vantage, then in Gods name march,
True Hope is ſwiﬅ, and ﬂyes with Swallowes wings,
Kings it makes Gods, and meaner creatures Kings.

scene.stagedir: Enter King Richard in Armes with Norfolke, Ratcliffe, and the Earle of Surrey.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Here pitch our Tent, euen here in Boſworth ﬁeld,
My Lord of Surrey, why looke you ſo ſad?

speech.speaker: Sur.
speech.line: My heart is ten times lighter then my lookes.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: My Lord of Norfolke.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Heere moſt gracious Liege.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Norfolke, we muſt haue knockes:
Ha, muſt we not?

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: We muſt both giue and take my louing Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Vp with my Tent, heere wil I lye to night,
But where to morrow? Well, all’s one for that.
Who hath deſcried the number of the Traitors?

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Six or ſeuen thouſand is their vtmoſt power.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why our Battalia trebbles that account:
Beſides, the Kings name is a Tower of ſtrength,
Which they vpon the aduerſe Faion want.
Vp with the Tent: Come Noble Gentlemen,
Let vs ſuruey the vantage of the ground.
Call for ſome men of ſound direion:
Let’s lacke no Diſcipline, make no delay,
For Lords, to morrow is a buſie day.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richmond, Sir William Branden, Oxford, and Dorſet.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: The weary Sunne, hath made a Golden ſet,
And by the bright Tra of his ﬁery Carre,
Giues token of a goodly day to morrow.
Sir William Brandon, you ſhall beare my Standard:
Giue me ſome Inke and Paper in my Tent:
Ile draw the Forme and Modell of our Battaile,
Limit each Leader to his ſeuerall Charge,
And part in iuſt proportion our ſmall Power.
My Lord of Oxford, you Sir William Brandon,
And your Sir Walter Herbert ſtay with me:
The Earle of Pembroke keepes his Regiment;
Good Captaine Blunt, beare my goodnight to him,
And by the ſecond houre in the Morning,
Deſire the Earle to ſee me in my Tent:
Yet one thing more (good Captaine) do for me:
Where is Lord Stanley quarter’d, do you know?

speech.speaker: Blunt.
speech.line: Vnleſſe I haue miſtane his Colours much,
(Which well I am aſſur’d I haue not done)
His Regiment lies halfe a Mile at leaſt
South, from the mighty Power of the King.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: If without perill it be poſſible,
Sweet Blunt, make ſome good meanes to ſpeak with him
And giue him from me, this moſt needfull Note.

speech.speaker: Blunt.
speech.line: Vpon my life, my Lord, Ile vndertake it,
And ſo God giue you quiet reſt to night.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: Good night good Captaine Blunt:
Come Gentlemen,
Let vs conſult vpon to morrowes Buſineſſe;
Into my Tent, the Dew is rawe and cold.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: What is’t a Clocke?

speech.speaker: Cat.
speech.line: It’s Supper time my Lord, it’s nine a clocke.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I will not ſup to night,
Giue me ſome Inke and Paper:
What, is my Beauer eaſier then it was?
And all my Armour laid into my Tent?

speech.speaker: Cat.
speech.line: It is my Liege: and all things are in readineſſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Good Norfolke, hye thee to thy charge,
Vſe carefull Watch, chooſe truſty Centinels,

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: I go my Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Stir with the Larke to morrow, gentle Norfolk.

speech.speaker: Nor
speech.line: I warrant you my Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ratcliffe.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Send out a Purſuiuant at Armes
To Stanleys Regiment: bid him bring his power
Before Sun-riſing, leaſt his Sonne George fall
Into the blinde Caue of eternall night.
Fill me a Bowle of Wine: Giue me a Watch,
Saddle white Surrey for the Field to morrow:
Look that my Staues be ſound, & not too heauy. Ratcliff.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Saw’ſt the melancholly Lord Northumberland?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Thomas the Earle of Surrey, and himſelfe,
Much about Cockſhut time, from Troope to Troope
Went through the Army, chearing vp the Souldiers.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: So, I am ſatisﬁed: Giue me a Bowle of Wine,
I haue not that Alacrity of Spirit,
Nor cheere of Minde that I was wont to haue.
Set it downe. Is Inke and Paper ready?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: It is my Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Bid my Guard watch. Leaue me.
Ratcliffe, about the mid of night come to my Tent
And helpe to arme me. Leaue me I ſay.

scene.stagedir: Enter Derby to Richmond in his Tent.

speech.speaker: Der.
speech.line: Fortune, and Viory ſit on thy Helme.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: All comfort that the darke night can affoord,
Be to thy Perſon, Noble Father in Law.
Tell me, how fares our Noble Mother?

speech.speaker: Der.
speech.line: I by Attourney, bleſſe thee from thy Mother,
Who prayes continually for Richmonds good:
So much for that. The ſilent houres ſteale on,
And ﬂakie darkeneſſe breakes within the Eaſt.
In breefe, for ſo the ſeaſon bids vs be,
Prepare thy Battell early in the Morning,
And put thy Fortune to th’ Arbitrement
Of bloody ſtroakes, and mortall ſtaring Warre:
I, as I may, that which I would, I cannot,
With beſt aduantage will deceiue the time,
And ayde thee in this doubtfull ſhocke of Armes.
But on thy ſide I may not be too forward,
leaſt being ſeene, thy Brother, tender George
Be executed in his Fathers ſight.
Farewell: the leyſure, and the fearfull time
Cuts off the ceremonious Vowes of Loue,
And ample enterchange of ſweet Diſcourſe,
Which ſo long ſundred Friends ſhould dwell vpon:
God giue vs leyſure for theſe rites of Loue.
Once more Adieu, be valiant, and ſpeed well.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: Good Lords condu him to his Regiment:
Ile ſtriue with troubled noiſe, to take a Nap,
Leſt leaden ſlumber peize me downe to morrow,
When I ſhould mount with wings of Viory:
Once more, good night kinde Lords and Gentlemen.
O thou, whoſe Captaine I account my ſelfe,
Looke on my Forces with a gracious eye:
Put in their hands thy bruiſing Irons of wrath,
That they may cruſh downe with a heauy fall,
Th’ vſurping Helmets of our Aduerſaries:
Make vs thy miniſters of Chaſticement,
That we may praiſe thee in thy viory:
To thee I do commend my watchfull ſoule,
Ere I let fall the windowes of mine eyes:
Sleeping, and waking, oh defend me ſtill.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Ghoſt of Prince Edward, Sonne to Henry the ſixt.

speech.speaker: Gh. to Ri.
speech.line: Let me ſit heauy on thy ſoule to morrow:
Thinke how thou ſtab’ſt me in my prime of youth
At Teukesbury: Diſpaire therefore, and dye.
Be chearefull Richmond,
For the wronged Soules
Of butcher’d Princes, ﬁght in thy behalfe:
King Henries iſſue Richmond comforts thee.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Ghoſt of Henry the ſixt.

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: When I was mortall, my Annointed body
By thee was punched full of holes;
Thinke on the Tower, and me: Diſpaire, and dye,
Harry the ſixt, bids thee diſpaire, and dye.
Vertuous and holy be thou Conqueror:
Harry that propheſied thou ſhould’ſt be King,
Doth comfort thee in ſleepe: Liue, and ﬂouriſh.

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: Let me ſit heauy in thy ſoule to morrow.
I that was waſh’d to death with Fulſome Wine:
Poore Clarence by thy guile betray’d to death:
To morrow in the battell thinke on me,
And fall thy edgeleſſe Sword, diſpaire and dye.
Thou off-ſpring of the houſe of Lancaſter
The wronged heyres of Yorke do pray for thee,
Good Angels guard thy battell, Liue and Flouriſh.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Ghoſts of Riuers, Gray, and Vaughan.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: Let me ſit heauy in thy ſoule to morrow,
Riuers, that dy’de at Pomfret: diſpaire, and dye.

speech.speaker: Grey.
speech.line: Thinke vpon Grey, and let thy ſoule diſpaire.

speech.speaker: Vaugh.
speech.line: Thinke vpon Vaughan, and with guilty feare
Let fall thy Lance, diſpaire and dye.
Awake,
And thinke our wrongs in Richards Boſome,
Will conquer him. Awake, and win the day.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Ghoſt of Lord Haſtings.

speech.speaker: Gho.
speech.line: Bloody and guilty: guiltily awake,
And in a bloody Battell end thy dayes.
Thinke on Lord Haſtings: diſpaire, and dye.
Quiet vntroubled ſoule,
Awake, awake:
Arme, ﬁght, and conquer, for faire Englands ſake.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Ghoſts of the two yong Princes.

speech.speaker: Ghoſts.
speech.line: Dreame on thy Couſins
Smothered in the Tower:
Let vs be laid within thy boſome Richard,
And weigh thee downe to ruine, ſhame, and death,
Thy Nephewes ſoule bids thee diſpaire and dye.
Sleepe Richmond,
Sleepe in Peace, and wake in Ioy,
Good Angels guard thee from the Boares annoy,
Liue, and beget a happy race of Kings,
Edwards vnhappy Sonnes, do bid thee ﬂouriſh.
speech.stagedir: Enter the Ghoſt of Anne, his Wife.
speech.line: Richard, thy Wife,
That wretched Anne thy Wife,
That neuer ſlept a quiet houre with thee,
Now ﬁlles thy ſleepe with perturbations,
To morrow in the Battaile, thinke on me,
And fall thy edgeleſſe Sword, diſpaire and dye:
Thou quiet ſoule,
Sleepe thou a quiet ſleepe:
Dreame of Succeſſe, and Happy Viory,
Thy Aduerſaries Wife doth pray for thee.
The ﬁrſt was I
That help’d thee to the Crowne:
That laſt was I that felt thy Tyranny.
O, in the Battaile think on Buckingham,
And dye in terror of thy guiltineſſe.
Dreame on, dreame on, of bloody deeds and death,
Fainting diſpaire; diſpairing yeeld thy breath.
I dyed for hope
Ere I could lend thee Ayde;
But cheere thy heart, and be thou not diſmayde:
God, and good Angels ﬁght on Richmonds ſide,
And Richard fall in height of all his pride.

scene.stagedir: Richard ſtarts out of his dreame.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Giue me another Horſe, bind vp my Wounds:
Haue mercy Ieſu. Soﬅ, I did but dreame.
O coward Conſcience? how doſt thou afﬂi me?
The Lights burne blew. It is not dead midnight.
Cold fearefull drops ſtand on my trembling ﬂeſh.
What? do I feare my ſelfe? There’s none elſe by,
Richard loues Richard, that is, I am I.
Is there a Murtherer heere? No; Yes, I am:
Then ﬂye; What from my ſelfe? Great reaſon: why?
Leſt I Reuenge. What? my ſelfe vpon my ſelfe?
Alacke, I loue my ſelfe. Wherefore? For any good
That I my ſelfe, haue done vnto my ſelfe?
O no. Alas, I rather hate my ſelfe,
For hatefull Deeds committed by my ſelfe.
I am a Villaine: yet I Lye, I am not.
Foole, of thy ſelfe ſpeake well: Foole, do not ﬂatter.
My Conſcience hath a thouſand ſeuerall Tongues,
And euery Tongue brings in a ſeuerall Tale,
And euerie Tale condemnes me for a Villaine;
Periurie, in the high’ſt Degree,
Murther, ſterne murther, in the dyr’ſt degree,
All ſeuerall ſinnes, all vs’d in each degree,
Throng all to’th’ Barre, crying all, Guilty, Guilty.
I ſhall diſpaire, there is no Creature loues me;
And if I die, no ſoule ſhall pittie me.
Nay, wherefore ſhould they? Since that I my Selfe,
Finde in my ſelfe, no pittie to my Selfe.
Me thought, the Soules of all that I had murther’d
Came to my Tent, and euery one did threat
To morrowes vengeance on the head of Richard.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Ratcliffe, my Lord, ’tis I: the early Village Cock
Hath twice done ſalutation to the Morne,
Your Friends are vp, and buckle on their Armour.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O Ratcliffe, I feare, I feare.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Nay good my Lord, be not affraid of Shadows.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: By the Apoſtle Paul, ſhadowes to night
Haue ſtroke more terror to the ſoule of Richard,
Then can the ſubſtance of ten thouſand Souldiers
Armed in proofe, and led by ſhallow Richmond.
’Tis not yet neere day. Come go with me,
Vnder our Tents Ile play the Eaſe-dropper,
To heare if any meane to ſhrinke from me.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Lords to Richmond ſitting in his Tent.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: Good morrow Richmond.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Cry mercy Lords, and watchfull Gentlemen,
That you haue tane a tardie ſluggard heere?

speech.speaker: Lords.
speech.line: How haue you ſlept my Lord?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The ſweeteſt ſleepe,
And faireſt boading Dreames,
That euer entred in a drowſie head,
Haue I ſince your departure had my Lords.
Me thought their Soules, whoſe bodies Rich. murther’d,
Came to my Tent, and cried on Viory:
I promiſe you my Heart is very iocond,
In the remembrance of ſo faire a dreame,
How farre into the Morning is it Lords?

speech.speaker: Lor.
speech.line: Vpon the ſtroke of foure.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why then ’tis time to Arme, and giue direſtion.
More then I haue ſaid, louing Countrymen,
The leyſure and inforcement of the time
Forbids to dwell vpon: yet remember this,
God, and our good cauſe, ﬁght vpon our ſide,
The Prayers of holy Saints and wronged ſoules,
Like high rear’d Bulwarkes, ſtand before our Faces,
( Richard except) thoſe whom we ﬁght againſt,
Had rather haue vs win, then him they follow.
For, what is he they follow? Truly Gentlemen,
A bloudy Tyrant, and a Homicide:
One rais’d in blood, and one in blood eſtabliſh’d;
One that made meanes to come by what he hath,
And ſlaughter’d thoſe that were the meanes to help him:
A baſe foule Stone, made precious by the ſoyle
Of Englands Chaire, where he is falſely ſet:
One that hath euer beene Gods Enemy.
Then if you ﬁght againſt Gods Enemy,
God will in iuſtice ward you as his Soldiers.
If you do ſweare to put a Tyrant downe,
You ſleepe in peace, the Tyrant being ſlaine:
If you do ﬁght againſt your Countries Fœs,
Your Countries Fat ſhall pay your paines the hyre.
If you do ﬁght in ſafegard of your wiues,
Your wiues ſhall welcome home the Conquerors.
If you do free your Children from the Sword,
Your Childrens Children quits it in your Age.
Then in the name of God and all theſe rights,
Aduance your Standards, draw your willing Swords.
For me, the ranſome of my bold attempt,
Shall be this cold Corpes on the earth’s cold face.
But if I thriue, the gaine of my attempt,
The leaſt of you ſhall ſhare his part thereof.
Sound Drummes and Trumpets boldly, and cheerefully,
God, and Saint George, Richmond, and Viory.

scene.stagedir: Enter King Richard, Ratcliffe, and Catesby.

speech.speaker: K.
speech.line: What ſaid Northumberland as touching Richmond?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: That he was neuer trained vp in Armes.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: He ſaid the truth: and what ſaid Surrey then?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: He ſmil’d and ſaid, the better for our purpoſe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: He was in the right, and ſo indeed it is.
Tell the clocke there.
Giue me a Kalender: Who ſaw the Sunne to day?

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: Not I my Lord.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then he diſdaines to ſhine: for by the Booke
He ſhould haue brau’d the Eaſt an houre ago,
A blacke day will it be to ſomebody. Ratcliffe.

speech.speaker: Rat.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: The Sun will not be ſeene to day,
The sky doth frowne, and lowre vpon our Army.
I would theſe dewy teares were from the ground.
Not ſhine to day? Why, what is that to me
More then to Richmond? For the ſelfe-ſame Heauen
That frownes on me, lookes ſadly vpon him.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Arme, arme, my Lord: the fœ vaunts in the ﬁeld.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Come, buſtle, buſtle. Capariſon my horſe.
Call vp Lord Stanley, bid him bring his power,
I will leade forth my Soldiers to the plaine,
And thus my Battell ſhal be ordred.
My Foreward ſhall be drawne in length,
Conſiſting equally of Horſe and Foot:
Our Archers ſhall be placed in the mid’ſt;
Iohn Duke of Norfolke, Thomas Earle of Surrey,
Shall haue the leading of the Foot and Horſe.
They thus direed, we will ﬂlow
In the maine Battell, whoſe puiſſance on either ſide
Shall be well-winged with our cheefeſt Horſe:
This, and Saint George to boote.
What think’ſt thou Norfolke.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: A good direion warlike Soueraigne,
This found I on my Tent this Morning.

line.emph: Iockey of Norfolke, be not ſo bold,
For Dickon thy maiſter is bought and ſold.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: A thing deuiſed by the Enemy.
Go Gentlemen, euery man to his Charge,
Let not our babling Dreames affright our ſoules:
For Conſcience is a word that Cowards vſe,
Deuis’d at ﬁrſt to keepe the ſtrong in awe,
Our ſtrong armes be our Conſcience, Swords our Law.
March on, ioyne brauely, let vs too’t pell mell,
If not to heauen, then hand in hand to Hell.
What ſhall I ſay more then I haue inferr’d?
Remember whom you are to cope withall,
A ſort of Vagabonds, Raſcals, and Run-awayes,
A ſcum of Brittaines, and baſe Lackey Pezants,
Whom their o’re-cloyed Country vomits forth
To deſperate Aduentures, and aſſur’d Deſtruion.
You ſleeping ſafe, they bring you to vnreſt:
You hauing Lands, and bleſt with beauteous wiues,
They would reſtraine the one, diſtaine the other,
And who doth leade them, but a paltry Fellow?
Long kept in Britaine at our Mothers coſt,
A Milke-ſop, one that neuer in his life
Felt ſo much cold, as ouer ſhoœs in Snow:
Let’s whip theſe ſtraglers o’re the Seas againe,
Laſh hence theſe ouer-weening Ragges of France,
Theſe famiſh’d Beggers, weary of their liues,
Who (but for dreaming on this fond exploit)
For want of meanes (poore Rats) had hang’d themſelues.
If we be conquered, let men conquer vs,
And not theſe baſtard Britaines, whom our Fathers
Haue in their owne Land beaten, bobb’d, and thump’d,
And on Record, leﬅ them the heires of ſhame.
Shall theſe enioy our Lands? lye with our Wiues?
Rauiſh our daughters?
Hearke, I heare their Drumme,
Right Gentlemen of England, ﬁght boldly yeomen,
Draw Archers draw your Arrowes to the head,
Spurre your proud Horſes hard, and ride in blood,
Amaze the welkin with your broken ſtaues.
What ſayes Lord Stanley, will he bring his power?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: My Lord, he doth deny to come.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Off with his ſonne Georges head.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: My Lord, the Enemy is paſt the Marſh:
Aﬅer the battaile, let George Stanley dye.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: A thouſand hearts are great within my boſom.
Aduance our Standards, ſet vpon our Fœs,
Our Ancient word of Courage, faire S. George
Inſpire vs with the ſpleene of ﬁery Dragons:
Vpon them, Viorie ſits on our helpes.

speech.speaker: Cat.
speech.line: Reſcue my Lord of Norfolke,
Reſcue, Reſcue:
The King enas more wonders then a man,
Daring an oppoſite to euery danger:
His horſe is ſlaine, and all on foot he ﬁghts,
Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death:
Reſcue faire Lord, or elſe the day is loſt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: A Horſe, a Horſe, my Kingdome for a Horſe.

speech.speaker: Cates.
speech.line: Withdraw my Lord, Ile helpe you to a Horſe

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Slaue, I haue ſet my life vpon a caſt,
And I will ſtand the hazard of the Dye:
I thinke there be ſixe Richmonds in the ﬁeld,
Fiue haue I ſlaine to day, in ſtead of him.
A Horſe, a Horſe, my Kingdome for a Horſe.

scene.stagedir: Alarum, Enter Richard and Richmond, they ﬁght, Richard is ſlaine.
Retreat, and Flouriſh. Enter Richmond, Derby bearing the Crowne, with diuers other Lords.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: God, and your Armes
Be prais’d Viorious Friends;
The day is ours, the bloudy Dogge is dead.

speech.speaker: Der.
speech.line: Couragious Richmond,
Well haſt thou acquit thee: Lœ,
Heere theſe long vſurped Royalties,
From the dead Temples of this bloudy Wretch,
Haue I pluck’d off, to grace thy Browes withall.
Weare it, and make much of it.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: Great God of Heauen, ſay Amen to all.
But tell me, is yong George Stanley liuing?

speech.speaker: Der.
speech.line: He is my Lord, and ſafe in Leiceſter Towne,
Whither (if you pleaſe) we may withdraw vs.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: What men of name are ſlaine on either ſide?

speech.speaker: Der.
speech.line: Iohn Duke of Norfolke, Walter Lord Ferris,
Sir Robert Brokenbury, and Sir William Brandon.

speech.speaker: Richm.
speech.line: Interre their Bodies, as become their Births,
Proclaime a pardon to the Soldiers ﬂed,
That in ſubmiſsion will returne to vs,
And then as we haue tane the Sacrament,
We will vnite the White Roſe, and the Red.
Smile Heauen vpon this faire Coniunion,
That long haue frown’d vpon their Enmity:
What Traitor heares me, and ſayes not Amen?
England hath long beene mad, and ſcarr’d her ſelfe;
The Brother blindely ſhed the Brothers blood;
The Father, raſhly ſlaughtered his owne Sonne;
The Sonne compell’d, beene Butcher to the Sire;
All this diuided Yorke and Lancaſter,
Diuided, in their dire Diuiſion.
O now, let Richmond and Elizabeth,
The true Succeeders of each Royall Houſe,
By Gods faire ordinance, conioyne together:
And let thy Heires (God if thy will be ſo)
Enrich the time to come, with Smooth-fac’d Peace,
With ſmiling Plenty, and faire Proſperous dayes.
Abate the edge of Traitors, Gracious Lord,
That would reduce theſe bloudy dayes againe,
And make poore England weepe in Streames of Blood;
Let them not liue to taſte this Lands increaſe,
That would with Treaſon, wound this faire Lands peace.
Now Ciuill wounds are ſtopp’d, Peace liues agen;
That ſhe may long liue heere, God ſay, Amen.
